Url.Title: Who Uses HEAT
Url.Abstract: Who Uses HEAT HEAT users generally fall into these categories:

Url.Title: Help Tips
Url.Abstract: Help Tips Use the following tips to enhance your access to the HEAT online help.

Url.Title: Customizing Help
Url.Abstract: Customizing Help You can customize the online help content to accommodate your specific needs. The online help is composed of HTML (.htm) files, among other types (.js, .xml). We recommend that you only modify the HTML files, as changing other files could break the help system. It is alright to add your own images.

Url.Title: Further Information
Url.Abstract: Further Information

Url.Title: Getting Started
Url.Abstract: Getting Started This topic provides a high-level view of how to get started using HEAT.

Url.Title: How HEAT Works
Url.Abstract: How HEAT Works HEAT communicates with a Microsoft SQL database to store and retrieve information, enabling multiple ways to enter and share data in a a customizable, object-oriented environment. HEAT supports Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, and IBM DB2 databases. You can link to other databases and import external database data.

Url.Title: Basics
Url.Abstract: Basics This section describes some of the basic features of HEAT .

Url.Title: How to Log In
Url.Abstract: How to Log In HEAT opens to the login page. Get the URL from your administrator. Enter your user name and password, then click Login.

Url.Title: Passwords
Url.Abstract: Passwords Passwords are created when user records are created by the administrator. Internal user passwords are stored in the user database, but external user passwords are not.

Url.Title: Changing Locales
Url.Abstract: Changing Locales If your administrator has given you privileges, you can change the language you see when using the application.

Url.Title: Navigation
Url.Abstract: Navigation After logging into HEAT, you see the Home page, which is one of the Dashboards. Different roles see different dashboards on their Home page.

Url.Title: Consoles
Url.Abstract: Consoles There are two working environments within HEAT: The Service Desk Console is where most users interact with the application, creating incidents, resolving problems, running reports, etc.

Url.Title: The Configuration Console (Admin UI)
Url.Abstract: The Configuration Console (Admin UI) The Configuration Console lets administrators set up the HEAT application for their organization. See Configure on how to use specific tools within the Configuration Console.

Url.Title: Using Dashboards
Url.Abstract: Using Dashboards Dashboards are user-defined summary views of HEAT data and can have one or more parts.

Url.Title: Alerts
Url.Abstract: Alerts Alerts are notices that appear at the top of a dashboard. A Sample Alert Notice By default, alerts appear in three categories:

Url.Title: Adding an Alert Bar to Your Home Page or Default Dashboard
Url.Abstract: Adding an Alert Bar to Your Home Page or Default Dashboard Alerts are added to your Home page or default dashboard through the Dashboard Center.

Url.Title: Creating an Alert Category
Url.Abstract: Creating an Alert Category You can create or modify the alert categories that appear on the Alert page. You can either add categories directly into the database, or create a workspace that enables users to add categories. The Alert Category workspace is not provided in the default version.

Url.Title: Using Workspaces
Url.Abstract: Using Workspaces Each tab represents a different workspace. A workspace consists of a toolbar, a search area, a dashboard, and sometimes an area for details of a record. Select a tab or workspace button from the top of the window to open and view the workspace.

Url.Title: Using Lists
Url.Abstract: Using Lists Lists appear in grids or table fields throughout the application. Double-click any record in a list to view details. You can also sort, group, and filter the records in the list to assist in locating the exact records you need and run quick actions against some or all of the records directly from the list. You can export the entire contents of the list as a .XLS file for use in Microsoft Excel or any other spreadsheet application that supports the .XLS file type.

Url.Title: Video: Filtering Records
Url.Abstract: Video: Filtering Records

Url.Title: Search
Url.Abstract: Search Search is available in most workspaces to help users to easily find records. Advanced searches can include expressions to fine-tune your search criteria. You can create a saved search, keeping frequently used criteria handy, and even designate a saved search as a favorite.

Url.Title: Using Full Text Search
Url.Abstract: Using Full Text Search Full text search quickly searches the text of the fields in each record of your database. Attachments designated as "searchable" are included in a text search.

Url.Title: Using Advanced Search
Url.Abstract: Using Advanced Search To get more precise search results, run an advanced search. Advanced searches enable you to define more parameters and provides more options than a simple text search.

Url.Title: Using Saved Searches
Url.Abstract: Using Saved Searches You can save your search criteria in a saved search. By saving searches, you can quickly perform a search task without the need to manually enter all of the search parameters each time. You can create, modify, and delete a saved search.

Url.Title: Exporting a Saved Search
Url.Abstract: Exporting a Saved Search You can export the records found in a saved search to a Microsoft Excel (.xls) file. You must have permissions granted by the administrator to do this.

Url.Title: Emailing a Saved Search
Url.Abstract: Emailing a Saved Search You can email the results of a saved search to yourself. You must have permissions granted by the administrator to do this.

Url.Title: Video: Creating a Saved Search
Url.Abstract: Video: Creating a Saved Search

Url.Title: Using Object Matching
Url.Abstract: Using Object Matching Object matching is a type of search that allows you to search other business objects while inside the current form. The search can originate in two ways:

Url.Title: Configuring Object Matching
Url.Abstract: Configuring Object Matching This topic describes how to configure object matching for Self Service users.

Url.Title: Using Related Items
Url.Abstract: Using Related Items When viewing or creating incident, problem, or knowledge records, a list of related items appears in the right pane of the window.

Url.Title: Using Record Search
Url.Abstract: Using Record Search Often with a form, you can link your record to another record. For example, you can link a configuration item to a change or problem record.

Url.Title: Tips for Running a Search
Url.Abstract: Tips for Running a Search Use the following suggestions to find the most accurate results. Search for Words

Url.Title: Search Examples
Url.Abstract: Search Examples This section describes some ways to use search.

Url.Title: Chat
Url.Abstract: Chat Chat has been added to the Social Board to increase ease of communication between users. Itis important to remember the following:

Url.Title: Chat with a Team, Group, or Role
Url.Abstract: Chat with a Team, Group, or Role You can have a conversation at the team level on Chat (as well as in the Social Board). You can only chat with teams, groups, or roles of which you are a member.

Url.Title: Social Board
Url.Abstract: Social Board You can post and view messages to other HEAT users. You can also create conversations amongst users within a team, group, or role. You must activate the Social Board before you can send or receive messages.

Url.Title: Messages and Comments
Url.Abstract: Messages and Comments View Messages There are three ways to view messages: Type of Messages There are two types of messages:

Url.Title: Posting a Message
Url.Abstract: Posting a Message You can post a message in the Social Board workspace or in the Chat pane. The following procedure describes using the Social Board workspace.

Url.Title: Posting a Comment
Url.Abstract: Posting a Comment Comments are messages that are added to an original message. To add a comment to a message received on the Social Board, click in the message text box and enter your message, then click Share or press Enter. The comment is shared to the all users receiving the original message.

Url.Title: Deleting Messages
Url.Abstract: Deleting Messages You can delete any post or comment that you own. Click Delete on the right hand side of the post or comment header.

Url.Title: Determining Who Can View a Message
Url.Abstract: Determining Who Can View a Message If a message has been sent to specific teams or groups, you can determine who is able to view a message. Giving a group access to a message does not guarantee that each member of the group has seen the message.

Url.Title: Updating Your Profile
Url.Abstract: Updating Your Profile Within the Social Board workspace, logged in users can upload a profile picture, and update their primary phone and alternative phone (the phone 2 field on the Employee form).

Url.Title: Preventing Profile Modification
Url.Abstract: Preventing Profile Modification From the Configuration Console, click Configure > Users and Permissions > Roles and Permissions.

Url.Title: Teams and Groups
Url.Abstract: Teams and Groups You can share conversations on the Social Board with specific teams and groups. In the Social Board, a team is defined by an administrator. A group can be created by any user.

Url.Title: Creating a Group
Url.Abstract: Creating a Group Create a Group in Your Social Board Within the Social Board workspace, click Groups Activity > Manage Groups. The Manage Groups window appears.

Url.Title: Joining a Group
Url.Abstract: Joining a Group You can join any group that you can see. Join a Group Within the Social Board workspace, click Groups Activity > Manage Groups. The Manage Groups window appears.

Url.Title: Leaving a Group
Url.Abstract: Leaving a Group Groups cannot be deleted, but you can leave a group. You cannot leave a group that you created.

Url.Title: Creating a Record from the Social Board
Url.Abstract: Creating a Record from the Social Board By default, HEAT provides the ability for you to create an incident, knowledge article, problem, release, or change from the Social Board. This capability can be extended to other objects.

Url.Title: Sharing a Business Object Record
Url.Abstract: Sharing a Business Object Record Share an incident, knowledge article, or change link from the business object record to the Social Board and add your comment.

Url.Title: Activating Social Board for Customers
Url.Abstract: Activating Social Board for Customers If you have disabled the Social Board to a role or a specific customer, then subsequently enable the Social Board, the administrator must grant access to existing tenants. After you have enabled the Social Board for customers and roles, subsequent users will automatically be granted Social Board access.

Url.Title: Adding the Social Board to a Role
Url.Abstract: Adding the Social Board to a Role To expose Social Service Management based on a role, first make the Social Board workspace available for selection in the Service Desk Configuration tab, and then use the Service Desk Configuration tab to grant Social Board workspace access to a role:

Url.Title: Social Business Objects and Relationships
Url.Abstract: Social Business Objects and Relationships The SocialFeeds business object has been introduced to support Social Service Management functionality.

Url.Title: Adding the Social Button to a Header Form
Url.Abstract: Adding the Share Button to a Header Form A special Share button can be added to the header forms for business objects, such as incident or change, to invoke the corresponding quick action for posting a message relative to the given record.

Url.Title: Activating Field Security Permissions
Url.Abstract: Activating Field Security Permissions The user's photo in the Social Board is stored using several fields in the Profile.Employee business object.

Url.Title: Related Posts
Url.Abstract: Related Posts Related posts appear under the Related Posts tab. If a knowledge article, change, incident, problem, or release record is created from the Social Board, the posting appears under the corresponding object.

Url.Title: Watch List
Url.Abstract: Watch List This feature must be set up by an administrator before it can be used. Watch List appears in the top tab bar area and is by default enabled for all roles except Self Service.

Url.Title: Configuring Watch List
Url.Abstract: Configuring Watch List You can create a place for users to store frequently-used business objects, similar to bookmarks or favorites. Watch List appears as a button on their top tab bar, and objects can be added by the user.

Url.Title: Use
Url.Abstract: Use This section describes how to use the Service Desk Console.

Url.Title: Self Service Quick Reference
Url.Abstract: Self Service Quick Reference Print this page and keep it handy.

Url.Title: About Self Service
Url.Abstract: About Self Service The Self Service dashboard is used by requesters (end users) and service owners. This dashboard provides a simpler interface and enables users to create, track, resolve, and close incidents and requests for service. Self Service users can also access FAQs, announcements, and knowledge center articles. The Self Service dashboard is designed to be intuitive and easy to use.

Url.Title: The Self Service Home Page
Url.Abstract: The Self Service Home Page The Self Service home page appears when you first log in. Self-help information is available from the following locations:

Url.Title: Get Help from the Knowledge Center
Url.Abstract: Get Help from the Knowledge Center The Knowledge Center gives you access to articles that might offer a solution to your issue. Knowledge Center articles differ from FAQs and announcements in these ways:

Url.Title: Providing Knowledge Feedback
Url.Abstract: Providing Knowledge Feedback Self Service users can rate and give feedback on specific knowledge articles.

Url.Title: Reporting an Incident
Url.Abstract: Reporting an Incident You can report an issue (also called an incident) using the Report an issue using template pane on the Self Service home page. See The Self Service Home Page for procedures on using this feature.

Url.Title: Tracking an Incident
Url.Abstract: Tracking an Incident While a Service Desk Analyst works to resolve your incident, you are able to: The system sends you periodic emails as a Service Desk Analyst works to resolve your incident. Some messages are routine notifications telling you that the status of your incident has changed. Other messages might ask you to provide additional information.

Url.Title: Updating an Incident
Url.Abstract: Updating an Incident Once an incident is in an active state (and is being worked on by a Service Desk Analyst), you cannot edit the form fields. However, you can update the incident by adding an attachment (such as a screen image, a document, and so on) or by adding additional information in a note.

Url.Title: Closing an Incident
Url.Abstract: Closing an Incident You can close any incident that you created, regardless of its current status. Typical reasons for closing your own incident include:

Url.Title: Requesting a Service
Url.Abstract: Requesting a Service Use the Top 5 Requests pane on the Self Service home page to submit a service request. See The Self Service Home Page.

Url.Title: Save for Later
Url.Abstract: Save for Later You can create a service request and save it without issuing a notification. You do not need to enter all the required information at this time.

Url.Title: Configuring Save For Later
Url.Abstract: Configuring Save For Later The Save For Later feature enables Self Service users to create a service request without immediate implementation.

Url.Title: Tracking a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Tracking a Service Request While a Service Desk Analyst works to fulfill your service request, you can do the following:

Url.Title: Updating a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Updating a Request You can update a service request by adding an attachment (such as a screen image, a document, and so on) or by adding additional information about the service request in a note.

Url.Title: Approving Requests
Url.Abstract: Approving Requests You can use Self Service to approve a knowledge article, release milestone completion, change, or a Self Service request.

Url.Title: Possible Solutions
Url.Abstract: Possible Solutions You can automatically find solutions to new issues. To create an issue that is not listed on any dashboard panes, click Report an Issue from the Report an Issue using Template pane. A blank issue template appears.

Url.Title: Finding Solutions in Announcements
Url.Abstract: Finding Solutions in Announcements Highest priority announcements (as determined by the system administrator) appear in the Announcement workspace.

Url.Title: Video: Creating an Incident
Url.Abstract: Video: Creating an Incident This tutorial shows how to create an incident while using Self Service.

Url.Title: Video Service Desk Analyst
Url.Abstract: Video: Service Desk Analyst This video describes the basic tasks of a Service Desk Analyst.

Url.Title: Video: Self Service Module
Url.Abstract: Video: Self Service Module

Url.Title: Analytic Metrics
Url.Abstract: Analytic Metrics You can track and visualize Service Management information, such as cost, value, and consumption. With Analytic Metrics, you can see your data graphically, not only charting current data, but also charting trends. The Analytic charts are flexible and customizable, and can be modified whenever you need it.

Url.Title: Metric Dashboards and Charts
Url.Abstract: Metric Dashboards and Charts

Url.Title: Multiple Series Chart Using Multiple Objects
Url.Abstract: Multiple Series Chart Using Multiple Objects This example shows how to create an Analytics chart that uses multiple series and multiple objects. This is useful to show trends.

Url.Title: Change
Url.Abstract: Change Topics In This Section

Url.Title: Creating a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Creating a Change Request Changes result from two factors: Changes are carefully controlled. Only users in authorized roles can work with the full change process. Most users interact with changes only when they submit change requests.

Url.Title: Approving a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Approving a Change Request

Url.Title: Change Approval Board
Url.Abstract: Change Approval Board

Url.Title: Managing Change Approvals
Url.Abstract: Managing Change Request Approvals

Url.Title: Scheduling a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Scheduling a Change Request

Url.Title: Working with Change Tasks for a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Working with Change Tasks for a Change Request

Url.Title: Implementing a Change
Url.Abstract: Implementing a Change

Url.Title: Post-Implementation Review
Url.Abstract: Post-Implementation Review After a change request is implemented, the change requires a post-implementation review.

Url.Title: Canceling a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Canceling a Change Request A new change request has a status of logged. If you want to cancel a change request, you must do so before you update the status to requested.

Url.Title: Resolving and Closing a Change Request
Url.Abstract: Resolving and Closing a Change Request You can close a change request after it is successfully implemented and reviewed.

Url.Title: Setting the Risk Level
Url.Abstract: Setting the Risk Level One of the key tasks or responsibilities of the Change Manager is to assess the risk of the change. Using the risk calculator, the Change Manager answers questions that determine the overall risk level for a specific change record.

Url.Title: Analyze and Classify Potential Change
Url.Abstract: Analyze and Classify Potential Change Effective Change Management involves the proper processing of Requests for Change (RFCs). Usually, a change is driven by a Configuration Item (CI) that has been identified in need of a change. The CI is usually the purpose for a change.

Url.Title: Attaching a Backout Plan to a Change
Url.Abstract: Attaching a Backout Plan to a Change Within the Attachment tab, add a backout plan (file) to a change record as an attachment.

Url.Title: Using the Change Calendar
Url.Abstract: Using the Change Calendar Changes, especially major and significant changes, can affect a large number of users in an organization. Organizations lose thousands of dollars and hours of work when employees are not notified or aware of impending changes that affect them. The HEAT change calendar provides greater visibility of impending changes in the organization.

Url.Title: Configuration
Url.Abstract: Configuration Configuration Items (CIs) are generally any component of an IT Infrastructure and typically include IT services, hardware, software, buildings, people and formal documentation such as process documentation and SLAs. Information about each CI is recorded in a configuration record and is maintained throughout its lifecycle by Configuration Management.

Url.Title: Working with CIs
Url.Abstract: Working with CIs

Url.Title: The CI Map
Url.Abstract: The CI Map The CI map tool gives you a way to visually look at a Configuration Item (CI) or Service and view the related Services or CIs (such as dependent on, hosted on, or managed by) in your organization.

Url.Title: CI Costing
Url.Abstract: CI Costing The Configuration Manager can add both direct item costs and indirect (or supporting) costs to a configuration item. In doing so, the total cost of providing a Service associated with a CI can be tracked, thus enabling budgeting and auditing of IT spending.

Url.Title: Linking CIs to Other Objects
Url.Abstract: Linking CIs to Other Objects Incident, problem, change, and release records can be created or linked from the Configuration Management workspace. If the configuration item record was created from an incident, problem, change, or release, then the record appears under the corresponding tab.

Url.Title: Setting up a Change Window and Lockout
Url.Abstract: Setting up a Change Window and Lockout The Configuration Manager can create a lockout period and a change window for a CI. The lockout period appears on the change scheduler in red, while the change window appears in green.

Url.Title: The Configuration Baseline
Url.Abstract: Configuration Baseline A configuration baseline shows the configuration of a CI that has been reviewed and agreed upon and is marked to be under change control.

Url.Title: Variance Reports
Url.Abstract: Variance Reports You can view a variance report to see all CIs that have been updated. The report shows as a dashboard part in the Configuration Manager dashboards.

Url.Title: Financial
Url.Abstract: Financial This section describes tasks related to Financial Management, such as measuring costs of service.

Url.Title: Cost Items
Url.Abstract: Cost Items A cost item is a specific line item within a transaction. Costs associated with a task are automatically added to an Incident or Service Request record. You can also manually add costs to these records. These cost items are listed in the Cost Item tab of the associated record, and in the ITFM Cost Item workspace, which is then used to compile data on all costs. See Task Costs.

Url.Title: Tracking Costs for an Incident
Url.Abstract: Tracking Costs for an Incident This topic shows how costs are tracked for an incident. You can use the same procedures to show costs for a service request item.

Url.Title: Exporting Costs to Excel
Url.Abstract: Exporting Costs to Excel You can export one or more of your cost items to a file and opened with MS Excel or other financial software.

Url.Title: Cost Filters
Url.Abstract: Cost Filters

Url.Title: Cost Driver
Url.Abstract: Cost Driver Cost drivers are a high-level cost calculators primarily used for reporting. These drivers are associated with price list items and services. When associated with a service, they define the primary cost drivers for the service (see CI Costing ). When associated with a price list item they define the default cost (see Price List).

Url.Title: Distribution
Url.Abstract: Distribution Distribution shows where costs are divided by various organizations. For example, you can offer a CRM service that is supported partially by Data Service and partially by Server Administration, showing the contribution percentage of each.

Url.Title: Allocation
Url.Abstract: Allocation Allocation shows subscribed services consumed and is automatically calculated based on the schedule Service Allocation Calculation Daily Schedule. For example, Data Service might provide 25% of it's total services to CRM Service. This cost is automatically calculated each month for CRM Service. The schedule gathers information daily, but provides data at the end of the month.

Url.Title: Incident
Url.Abstract: Incident An incident is an unplanned interruption or reduction in quality of an IT service, or a break in the standard operation of a service. The details of an incident and its complete history from registration to resolution are recorded in an incident record.

Url.Title: Working with Incidents
Url.Abstract: Working with Incidents A Requester (or Customer) can submit incidents and requests for services directly to the Service Desk using the Self Service module, or by phone or email to the service desk. For all modules, a unique reference number (RecId) and date time stamp (CreatedDateTime) is automatically generated for each newly created record.

Url.Title: Assigning an Incident
Url.Abstract: Assigning an Incident When the requester calls the service desk to report an incident, the incident owner defaults to the Service Desk Analyst logging the incident and the team defaults to the team to which the analyst belongs. If the analyst is able to resolve the incident for the customer, it is considered a first call resolution and the analyst and analyst's team remain the Team and Owner to whom the incident is issued.

Url.Title: Incident Escalations
Url.Abstract: Incident Escalations Events are monitored by an escalation clock. If an event does not occur within a prescribed period of time, an escalation action is executed. The exact timing and actions of an escalation depend on how your system is configured.

Url.Title: Linking Assets
Url.Abstract: Linking Assets While working on an incident, you could determine that the incident is either part of an existing change, problem, release, or other record type. For example, you might notice that several incidents have been logged against the same configuration item. Upon further review, you determine that the incidents are actually part of the same problem.

Url.Title: Investigating an Incident
Url.Abstract: Investigating an Incident The goal of the Service Desk is to restore normal service at the initial point of contact with the customer or requester. An incident resolved at the initial point of contact is called First Call Resolution. On the incident form, indicate if the incident was resolved at the initial point of contact by selecting First Call Resolution under the Resolution tab of the incident form.

Url.Title: Responding to Incidents
Url.Abstract: Responding to Incidents When an incident is submitted by a requester through the Self Service module, its initial status is set to Logged. The incident's status is changed to another state when the SDA assigns an owner. The amount of time that the incident is in the Logged state is the incident response time. If incident response time exceeds a prescribed duration, a notification shows on the Service Desk Management dashboard, and a breached status is indicated on the Response progress bar.

Url.Title: Resolving Incidents
Url.Abstract: Resolving Incidents You can resolve the incident after working on it and after its associated tasks are completed or the Service Desk can escalate the incident for further research, management action, or problem initiation.

Url.Title: Closing Incidents
Url.Abstract: Closing Incidents Coding and closing the incident lets you determine when incidents are resolved and helps you classify root causes.

Url.Title: Task-Incident Workflow
Url.Abstract: Task-Incident Workflow Incidents containing tasks need to have agreement before completion. In other words, an incident should not be able to be closed if it contains open tasks. Also, once all tasks within an incident are closed, then the incident should be automatically resolved, or a new task automatically created. However, an incident can be closed regardless of the tasks status, automatically closing any open tasks.

Url.Title: Inventory
Url.Abstract: Inventory Inventory is a collection of assets, and is used with Configuration Management. Inventory includes FrontRange Discovery and FrontRange Desktop and Server Management (DSM) components.

Url.Title: Using Audits
Url.Abstract: Using Audits

Url.Title: Running an Active Directory Scan
Url.Abstract: Running an Active Directory Scan After the gateway is first installed, you need to use the Scan Active Directory option to scan the network for computers that are not audited.

Url.Title: Manage Inventory Settings
Url.Abstract: Managing Inventory Settings Within the Inventory Settings workspace you can specify and manage the auditing of assets in a given organizational unit.

Url.Title: Manage Gateway Settings
Url.Abstract: Managing Gateway Settings The Inventory Manager can manage settings from the Gateway workspace.

Url.Title: DSM
Url.Abstract: DSM FrontRange Solutions Desktop and Server Management (DSM) aids IT organizations with automating, regulating, and simplifying how desktops and servers are managed. By automating routine IT management tasks such as deploying applications, planning major operating system rollouts, provisioning new employees, applying patches, and modifying your settings, DSM can be the key to reducing IT expenditure.

Url.Title: DSM Features
Url.Abstract: DSM Features The DSM integration with HEAT provides the following features in HEAT for Service Desk Analysts:

Url.Title: Reporting an issue to install software or reprovision computer
Url.Abstract: Reporting an Issue to Install Software or Reprovision Computer

Url.Title: Viewing CIs in the Managed Software Workspace
Url.Abstract: Viewing Configuration Items in the Managed Software Workspace As a Service Desk Analyst, you can open the Managed Software workspace to view (but not change) managed software, its status, and other information.

Url.Title: Knowledge
Url.Abstract: Knowledge The primary role of knowledge is to improve the quality of decision making by ensuring that accurate, reliable and trustworthy information is available throughout the service lifecycle. Knowledge is a collection of articles describing solutions and answers to Service Desk questions.

Url.Title: Creating a Knowledge Article
Url.Abstract: Creating a Knowledge Article

Url.Title: Feedback
Url.Abstract: Working with Knowledge Feedback The Feedback tab appears within a knowledge record and lets you see what feedback users have provided as well as enter your own feedback items.

Url.Title: Related Articles
Url.Abstract: Linking Related Articles to a Knowledge Article You can link knowledge articles that contain related information to another knowledge article from the Related Articles tab. Self Service users automatically see the related articles when they view the main knowledge article.

Url.Title: Approving Knowledge Articles
Url.Abstract: Approving a Knowledge Article

Url.Title: The Knowledge Approval Workflow
Url.Abstract: The Knowledge Approval Workflow The following topic describes the default approval workflow for knowledge articles. Your administrator may have modified the default workflow.

Url.Title: Configure Approvers and Approval Workflows
Url.Abstract: Configuring Approvers and Approval Workflows for Knowledge Articles

Url.Title: Setting up the Knowledge Advisory Board
Url.Abstract: Setting up the Knowledge Advisory Boards

Url.Title: Publishing a Knowledge Article
Url.Abstract: Publishing a Knowledge Article When an article goes through the approval process and is approved, the article status is updated to reviewed. A Knowledge Manager then has the option to review the article again or promote it to published status.

Url.Title: Archiving or Expiring a Knowledge Article
Url.Abstract: Archiving or Expiring a Knowledge Article Expiring an article usually means that it is time-sensitive, such as a knowledge article on a product version that is no longer supported. You might want to archive an article that is inaccurate (and replace it with another one) or one that has not been viewed over a period of time in Self Service.

Url.Title: Video: Knowledge
Url.Abstract: Video: Working with Knowledge Bases

Url.Title: Mobile
Url.Abstract: Mobile Layouts HEAT can be viewed on mobile devices through a browser. All user functions operate the same as on a desktop browser. We recommend access to as large a screen as possible; therefore a tablet is more practical than a smart phone for using HEAT. See Client Computer Requirements for information on compatible browsers.

Url.Title: Problem
Url.Abstract: Problems A problem is defined as multiple incidents exhibiting common symptoms or a single incident with no known cause. The primary objective of Problem Management is to prevent incidents from happening and to minimize the impact of incidents that cannot be prevented. Proactive Problem Management analyzes incident records, and uses data collected by other HEAT processes to identify trends or significant problems.

Url.Title: Managing Problems
Url.Abstract: Managing Problems

Url.Title: Working with Problems
Url.Abstract: Working with Problems Problems can be logged by users other than the Problem Manager. Problems are usually logged from other sources, including Incident Management by the Service Desk Analysts working on incidents.

Url.Title: Problem Status
Url.Abstract: Creating a Custom Problem Status You can create a custom status for a problem, and determine the order of transition for the custom state.

Url.Title: Resolving Problems
Url.Abstract: Resolving a Problem A problem can be resolved with a temporary workaround. However, entering a resolution does not always mean that the problem is closed.

Url.Title: Closing Problems
Url.Abstract: Closing a Problem After a problem is set to resolved, you can close the record. Log into the Service Desk Console as a Problem Manager, and from the Problem workspace, open the problem that you want to resolve.The problem must be in the active status.

Url.Title: Problem Review Board (PRB)
Url.Abstract: Working with the Problem Review Board (PRB) The goal of the Problem Review Board is to manage problems. This is done through analyzing incidents as they happen, reviewing historic trend data, and staying current with industry news and vendor updates.

Url.Title: Release
Url.Abstract: Releases Release encompasses planning, design, build, configuration and testing of hardware and software releases to create a comprehensive release strategy. Release Managers and administrators can view releases.

Url.Title: Working with Releases
Url.Abstract: Working with Releases The Release Manager or the Change Manager can create releases. Change Managers often create a release while working on a change.

Url.Title: Creating a Milestone
Url.Abstract: Working with Milestones If you use the release templates to create a release of type major, defined milestones are created. You also have the option of creating custom milestones from the Quick Actions menu, from the Milestones tab, or from the Schedule tab using the Gantt chart.

Url.Title: Release Stakeholders
Url.Abstract: Release Stakeholders Users in the application can be identified as stakeholders for a Release. You can select a user and link that user to the Release record. The user is notified as being the stakeholder for the Release. Stakeholders might have a stake in the outcome of the Release and work with the Release Approval Board to make sure that approved processes are followed in implementing and deploying a Release.

Url.Title: Canceling a Release
Url.Abstract: Canceling a Release A new release record is in a state of draft. You can leave it in this state while you are gathering information to enter. When you are ready to submit the release, update its status to requested. If you decide to cancel the release, you can do so before you update the release status to requested, unless you are the Release Manager.

Url.Title: Approving Releases
Url.Abstract: Approving Releases Only Release Types of Major require approval; therefore, five different workflows have been defined to accommodate the various combinations of Major Releases. They are:

Url.Title: Approving Milestones
Url.Abstract: Approving Milestones When a major release is updated to active status, the approval workflow is started. After the approvers approve the first milestone in the sequence after the milestone status is updated to completed, the next milestone in the sequence is started. After all the milestones defined for a release are approved, the release is updated to closed status.

Url.Title: About the Release Review Board
Url.Abstract: About the Release Review Board After each milestone is completed, the Release Review Board is notified to do a post implementation review of the milestone. See Working with Milestones.

Url.Title: Managing a Release Project using the Gantt chart
Url.Abstract: Managing a Release Project using the Gantt chart You can create milestones and tasks for a release using the Schedule tab of the release record. The Schedule tab contains a Gantt chart view of the project that you can set up and manage from the Gantt chart itself.

Url.Title: Linking CIs and Services to a Release
Url.Abstract: Linking CIs and Services to a Release Affected CIs and the impacted services affected by a change are directly linked to the change from the change record. When the change is linked to a release, Search and Link quick action business rules automatically link all associated CIs and services from the change to the release.

Url.Title: Working with Related Releases
Url.Abstract: Working with Related Releases You can link to or create other Releases that are related to the current Release.

Url.Title: Working with Release Packages
Url.Abstract: Working with Release Packages A Release Package contains information about all the CIs (for example, documentation, test plans, services, and so on) associated with a Change and links to the Release that is deploying the Change.

Url.Title: Service Catalog
Url.Abstract: Service Catalog The Service Catalog lists request offerings, such as requests for software, computers, or email.

Url.Title: Request Offerings
Url.Abstract: Request Offerings Request offerings are items that describe the item, assistance, or action available to customers from the service catalog. Request offerings are normally placed in logical groups of service offerings. Both service offerings and their request offerings are available to Self Service users when the status of the offerings is set to published and if end users have been assigned a corresponding Service Manager user role. Only users who have been assigned a user role associated with a catalog group that contains catalog items can use the Self-Service portal to access the service catalog.

Url.Title: Working with Request Offerings
Url.Abstract: Working with Request Offerings Request offerings are created by Service Owners and can be used by Self Service users in the Service Catalog.

Url.Title: Request Offerings Default Icons
Url.Abstract: Request Offerings Default Icons Listed are the default images (icons) used within request offerings. These images appear to users in the Service Catalog.

Url.Title: Price List
Url.Abstract: Price List The Price List workspace enables you to set different prices for services based on the regional settings for a user. You can define prices for all items (including services and subscriptions) within a single global list.

Url.Title: Request Form Examples
Url.Abstract: Request Form Examples

Url.Title: Cascading Validation List
Url.Abstract: Using a Cascading Validation List This example illustrates how to trigger values from additional fields or a combo box (cascading validation list) by creating a service that uses a value based on the field OwnerTeam.

Url.Title: Using Multiple Currencies
Url.Abstract: Using Multiple Currencies You can create different prices for users depending on where the customer is located. You can combine different currencies within a single Service Catalog offering.

Url.Title: Exporting a Request Offering
Url.Abstract: Exporting a Request Offering You can export a request offering template to your local drive. Within the Request Offering workspace, click Save Template on a Disk next to the request offering that you want to copy.

Url.Title: Deleting a Request Offering
Url.Abstract: Deleting a Request Offering After you create and publish a request offering, you can hide or delete it:

Url.Title: Service Requests
Url.Abstract: Service Requests An end-user request that is not a failure (incident) is a request for service (service request). Service requests are usually initiated within the Self Service dashboard.

Url.Title: Creating a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Working with Service Requests Self Service users typically create their own service requests from within the Self Service dashboard. However, a Service Desk Analyst or Change Manager can create a new service request on behalf of a requester using the Service Request workspace. The Request Offering workspace is available to the Change Manager.

Url.Title: Creating Software and Provisioning Service Requests
Url.Abstract: Creating Software and Provisioning Service Requests When Self Service users create a service request to install software or provision computers, Service Desk Analysts can view and make updates to the service request from the Service Request workspace.

Url.Title: Installing and Provisioning Incidents
Url.Abstract: Installing and Provisioning Incidents Service Desk Analysts can use the Incident workspace to install software and provision computers for other users in the organization. Using the Incident form, the Service Desk Analyst can do the following:

Url.Title: Reprovisioning a Computer
Url.Abstract: Reprovisioning a Computer You can only reprovision a computer that already has an operating system set installed.

Url.Title: Pending Service Requests
Url.Abstract: Pending Service Requests You might want to create a service request, but do not have all the required information. If the required information is not entered, the service request cannot be saved. However, you can save a draft, or Pending, version of the service request.

Url.Title: Video: Creating a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Video: Creating a Service Request

Url.Title: Service Request Escalations
Url.Abstract: Service Request Escalations Various events are monitored by an escalation clock. If an event does not occur within a prescribed period of time, an escalation action is executed. The exact timing and actions of an escalation depend on how your system is configured.

Url.Title: Multi-Item Requests
Url.Abstract: Multi-Item Requests Multi-item requests allow users to request more than one item in a single request form. For example, a multi-item request could allow a user to select one or more items from a list of available products and services such as software packages, account creation, and so on.

Url.Title: Creating Multi-Item Requests
Url.Abstract: Creating Multi-Item Requests This topic gives an overview of the procedures required to configure multi-item requests.

Url.Title: Task & Software Installation Catalogs
Url.Abstract: Task and Software Installation Catalogs Task catalogs define manual tasks that an SDA performs when fulfilling multi-item requests. Software installation catalogs define tasks that run automatically to install one or more DSM-managed software packages.

Url.Title: Fulfillment Item Packages
Url.Abstract: Fulfillment Item Packages A fulfillment item package defines a requestable item, the tasks that are performed to fulfill the item, and which organizational units are entitled to select the item. When a Service Catalog user submits a request for a fulfillment item package, fulfillment items based on the fulfillment item package are created and added to the resulting Service Request.

Url.Title: Fulfillment Items
Url.Abstract: Fulfillment Items A fulfillment item is the runtime instance of a fulfillment item package. It contains a list of tasks for delivering the fulfillment item and one or more workflows for task execution.

Url.Title: Fulfill Multiple Software Requests
Url.Abstract: Fulfill Multiple Software Requests This topic describes how a Service Desk Analyst can fulfill a default multiple software service request submitted from the Service Catalog. You select which software items to install, then the installation is automatically deployed through DSM.

Url.Title: Approving Service Requests
Url.Abstract: Approving Service Requests When a service rquest requires approval, an approval record is created in the Approval tab of the service request record in pending status. An approval email notification is sent to the manager of the organizational unit of the customer.

Url.Title: Canceling a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Canceling a Service Request Service requests cannot be deleted, but they can be canceled. This procedure changes their status to canceled, but keeps the service request in the system.

Url.Title: Closing a Service Request
Url.Abstract: Closing a Service Request A service request is considered closed when the status is fulfilled or closed.

Url.Title: Using the Survey
Url.Abstract: Using the Survey When an incident is closed, the user is invited by email to participate in a survey. It is important for users to provide feedback to the Service Desk about their effectiveness. From the incident module, the SDA can log information for on-demand customer feedback by logging the feedback by creating an incident with the category of Feedback.

Url.Title: Service Levels
Url.Abstract: Service Level Management ITIL Service Level Management aims to negotiate Service Level Agreements with the customers and to design services in accordance with the agreed service level targets. Service Level Management is also responsible for ensuring that all operational level agreements and underpinning contracts are appropriate, and to monitor and report on service levels.

Url.Title: SLM Dashboard
Url.Abstract: SLM Dashboard The SLM Dashboard gives you a snapshot of SLTs, while enabling you to drill down and view certain details.

Url.Title: Creating a Service
Url.Abstract: Creating a Service You can create a service to offer to your customers. If your organization provides multiple services (such as Web Hosting or Mobile Communications), then you can link separate Service Agreements and Service Level Packages based on each.

Url.Title: Service Level Targets
Url.Abstract: Service Level Targets A Service Level Target (SLT) is a key element of a service level agreement (SLA) between a service provider and a customer. SLTs are agreed as a means of measuring the performance of the service provider and are outlined as a way of avoiding disputes between the two parties based on misunderstanding.

Url.Title: Creating a Team
Url.Abstract: Creating a Team Teams (as used in the context of Service Agreements) are also known as Groups, Entities, Departments, Organizational Units, and many other names. They are used to create Operational Level Agreements within a service provider organization.

Url.Title: Creating a Vendor
Url.Abstract: Creating a Vendor Vendor records must be created before you can create Underpinning Contracts. Vendors are service providers outside your organization.

Url.Title: Retiring a Service
Url.Abstract: Retiring a Service You can retire a Service that is no longer used. Log into the Service Desk Console as the Service Owner and open the Services workspace.

Url.Title: Service Tab
Url.Abstract: Service You can link a record to specific service items from the Service tab.

Url.Title: Service Level Agreements
Url.Abstract: Service Level Agreements ITIL defines a Service Level Agreement as an Agreement between an IT Service Provider and a Customer. The SLA describes the IT Service, documents Service Level Targets, and specifies the responsibilities of the IT Service Provider and the Customer. A single SLA may cover multiple IT Services or multiple Customers.

Url.Title: Service Level Packages
Url.Abstract: Service Level Packages Service level packages describe the level of service offered to a customer. A service level package is a service that has been packaged by the Service Level Manager or service owner, and can be subscribed to by an organizational unit. The package specifies target times for incident response and resolution. If the Service Catalog and the Request Fulfillment module are installed, the service level package also specifies which request offerings are available as well as a target time for service request delivery.

Url.Title: Operational Level Agreements
Url.Abstract: Operational Level Agreements An Operational Level Agreement (OLA) defines the interdependent relationships among the internal support groups of an organization working to support a service-level agreement (SLA). The agreement describes the responsibilities of each internal support group toward other support groups, including the process and time-frame for delivery of their services. The objective of the OLA is to present a clear, concise and measurable description of the service provider's internal support relationships. An OLA helps ensure that activities performed by a number of support team components are clearly aligned to provide the intended SLA.

Url.Title: Underpinning Contracts
Url.Abstract: Underpinning Contracts ITIL defines an Underpinning Contract as a Contract between an IT Service Provider and a Third Party. The Third Party provides goods or Services that support delivery of an IT Service to a Customer. The Underpinning Contract defines targets and responsibilities that the Service Provider will use to determine Service Level Targets and Packages.

Url.Title: Subscribing to a Service
Url.Abstract: Subscribing to a Service Content not yet available. Dragon.

Url.Title: Services Workspace Index
Url.Abstract: Services Workspace Index The following table lists the workspaces related to services, agreements, request offerings, and service requests. The main workspaces used are highlighted.

Url.Title: Voice
Url.Abstract: Voice You can use FrontRange Voice, also known as IPCM (IP Communications Management), with HEAT to make the Service Desk accessible over the phone to customers and for agent-to-agent phone communication within your organization. Using the integrated Voice toolbar, Service Desk Analysts or agents do not need to leave the Cloud environment to answer calls from customers, transfer calls to other agents, conference in other agents, etc.

Url.Title: Creating Incidents Using IPCM
Url.Abstract: Creating Incidents Using IPCM When IPCM is configured to create incidents from phone calls, customers can call the Service Desk number, following the computer instructions. The system automatically creates an incident from the phone call.

Url.Title: Common Features
Url.Abstract: Common Features This section describes features common to all modules.

Url.Title: Activity History
Url.Abstract: Activity History Activity history stores all the emails and notes related to the current record. You can also view notes from associated tasks.

Url.Title: Notes and Comments
Url.Abstract: Notes and Comments By default, comments associated with tasks for a specific record appear in the Activity History tab of the record. You can choose to view or hide notes from tasks associated with the business object.

Url.Title: Attachments and URLs
Url.Abstract: Attachments and URLs You can attach files or images to records, enabling users to view extra data not limited by the defined fields. Many HEAT workspaces allow Attachments and URLs to a record, including incidents, knowledge articles, tasks, problems, change requests, releases, and service requests. Administrators can limit the size and type of attachments allowed (see Other Form Controls). Attachments to knowledge articles can be designated as searchable (see Searchable Attachments).

Url.Title: Searchable Attachments
Url.Abstract: Searchable Attachments You can attach a document to a knowledge article that can be found during a search. This document is enabled for a full text search. File formats supported are txt, doc, docx, xls, xlsx. Other formats can be attached here, but will not be searchable.

Url.Title: Attachment Types
Url.Abstract: Attachment Types The default attachment types are:

Url.Title: Announcements and FAQs
Url.Abstract: Announcements and FAQs You can create announcements and FAQs to view. Announcements and FAQs appear on the Home page.

Url.Title: Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Quick Actions A quick action is a user-defined operation that enables you to perform a series of actions or advanced functions with a single click. For example, a quick action can copy an account file or send a confirmation notification upon receipt of an email. Quick actions are handy for often-used activities.

Url.Title: Using Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Using Quick Actions A quick action can be run against the currently active record or against records in a grid.

Url.Title: Add Fields to a Quick Action
Url.Abstract: Adding Fields to a Quick Action You can add fields to a quick action when creating a new action. Additional fields give you more control over the results of your quick action.

Url.Title: Add Actions to Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Adding Actions to a Quick Action By default, quick actions are created with one action. But sometimes you might want to create a more complex quick action that involves multiple actions.

Url.Title: Cloning a Quick Action
Url.Abstract: Cloning a Quick Action You can create an exact copy of a quick action, then easily modify any parameter.

Url.Title: Adding Quick Action Buttons to the Workspace Toolbar
Url.Abstract: Adding Quick Action Buttons to the Workspace Toolbar You can add quick action buttons to the Object Form Toolbar. The default buttons (New, Delete, Refresh and Action Menu) are not quick action buttons and cannot be deleted or selected while in quick action configuration mode (as indicated by the lock button).

Url.Title: Creating a QA Template
Url.Abstract: Create a Quick Action Template A powerful use for quick actions involves creating a template—a record with several fields already completed by default. An example of such a template is the Desktop Application Failure template, used to create incident records when such failures are reported. You can create such a template as part of a Form quick action.

Url.Title: Creating a Report QA
Url.Abstract: Creating a Report Quick Action You can use the Create Report quick action to run an existing report against selected records. For example, you can create a printable report that lists selected items in a record.

Url.Title: Creating an Export Data Quick Action
Url.Abstract: Creating an Export Data Quick Action You can create a quick action that exports either an ad hoc or a scheduled report.

Url.Title: Translating the Self Service QA Templates
Url.Abstract: Translating the Self Service Quick Action Templates The Self Service templates in the Quick Actions Center of the Incident workspace are available for self service requesters to use.

Url.Title: Using the Send Email QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Send Email Quick Action You can use the Send Email quick action to send a notification email to interested parties (requester, owner, and so on) when the record is in a specific state. For example, you can create Send Email quick actions to send notification emails to the Incident Owner Team when a new incident is assigned.

Url.Title: Using the Clone Object QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Clone Object Quick Action You can use the Clone Object quick action to copy and overwrite the specified fields from a business object record. You can set up the quick action to only overwrite certain fields on a business object record, as shown in the following example of the Clone Object quick action in the Incident workspace:

Url.Title: Using the Update Object QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Update Object Quick Action You can use the Update Object quick action to update certain fields on a business object. For example, you can manage email statuses, as described in Email Examples.

Url.Title: Using the Insert Child Object QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Insert Child Object Quick Action You can use the Insert Child Object quick action to create a child object for a business object. For example, you can define a quick action to create a new task object each time a change is set to logged.

Url.Title: Using the Export to Excel QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Export to Excel Quick Action You can use the Export to Excel quick action to export all or some of the field values from a business object to a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. For example, you can export some of the field values from a Change record to an Excel spreadsheet.

Url.Title: Using the Run Program Quick Action
Url.Abstract: Using the Run Program Quick Action This procedure describes how to create a quick action that executes a file or script on a remote server.

Url.Title: Using the Run for Child QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Run for Child Quick Action Use the Run for Child quick action to perform an action on a child object of a business object. For example, you might want to notify a Release Milestone Owner when a Release Milestone is in Active status. Release is the object and Milestone is the child.

Url.Title: Using the UI Action QA to Open a Workflow
Url.Abstract: Using the UI Action Quick Action to Open a Workflow The following example shows how you can use a UI Action quick action to show the approval process of a Change.

Url.Title: Using the UI Action QA to Open Another Workspace
Url.Abstract: Using the UI Action Quick Action to Open Another Workspace In the following example, you can use the UI Action quick action to open a change form from the Problem workspace.

Url.Title: Using the Search and Link QA
Url.Abstract: Using the Search and Link Quick Action You can use the Search and Link quick action to perform an action on a child object of another child object that is associated to a business object. For example, you might want to search for all Configuration Items (CIs) associated to a Change that is associated to a Release in order to directly link all the CIs from the Change to the Release.

Url.Title: Quick Action Expression Examples
Url.Abstract: Quick Action Expression Examples The following examples show how expressions can be used to enhance quick actions.

Url.Title: Reports
Url.Abstract: Reports A report is a display of information captured from the HEAT database. Reports provide IT managers, service owners, and other organizational stakeholders the ability to measure operational, cost, and user satisfaction metrics by showing data from the IT organization in a meaningful and organized manner. HEAT comes with default reports that users can access to view IT-related data. See Default Reports.

Url.Title: Running a Report
Url.Abstract: Viewing Reports To make a report available to a certain user role, the administrator must do the following first:

Url.Title: Creating Reports & Templates
Url.Abstract: Creating Reports and Templates Creating reports is a function of the administrator or Report Manager role. If the Report tab is to appear to another role, the administrator needs to make the tab available to that role.

Url.Title: Scheduling a Report
Url.Abstract: Scheduling a Report You can schedule a report to run at specific times. Within the Report workspace in the Schedule Information section, choose from the following:

Url.Title: Printing Reports
Url.Abstract: Printing Reports In general, reports are printed using the print function within your browser.

Url.Title: Exporting a Report
Url.Abstract: Exporting a Report You can export a report to a text file and use it within other applications, such as Microsoft Excel or Microsoft Word.

Url.Title: Sending a Report by Email
Url.Abstract: Sending a Report by Email Reports can be scheduled and automatically generated. Scheduled reports can be emailed to one or more users.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Reports
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Reports This topic contains answers to some common report issues.

Url.Title: Report Examples
Url.Abstract: Report Examples The following use cases are provided as examples to help you create a report template with parameters, upload it to HEAT, publish it, and then run it.

Url.Title: Tasks
Url.Abstract: Tasks A task is a unit of work that must be completed while an incident or a problem is being resolved, or while a change or release is being implemented.

Url.Title: Creating a Task
Url.Abstract: Creating a Task While working on a parent object such as an incident, a change, a problem, or a release milestone, you can create tasks to complete work on the parent object. These tasks can then be assigned to different owners.

Url.Title: Using External Tasks
Url.Abstract: Using External Tasks External tasks are tasks that are acted upon by outside organizations, usually with whom you have a contract for services. For example, if your business provides a Web Hosting service. While you might be able to provide some services internally (such as web development or email), you might have an agreement with an outside vendor to provide various levels of access for your customers (fast, medium, or normal, for example).

Url.Title: Working on a Task
Url.Abstract: Working on a Task It is recommended that tasks linked to a parent object be completed before the parent object is set to resolved or closed. If the default workflow for some parent objects do not enforce rules for completing child tasks before the parent can be resolved, best practice is to manually set tasks to completed status when the parent object is closed or work with your administrator to set up business rules or workflow for managing tasks.

Url.Title: Assigning a Task
Url.Abstract: Assigning a Task If the owner is not specified during task creation, a task can be assigned to a team. The team manager can then assign an owner to a task.

Url.Title: Reassigning a Task
Url.Abstract: Reassigning a Task If you are unable to work on a task or if the task is escalated, you might have to reassign the task.

Url.Title: Task Escalations
Url.Abstract: Task Escalations Various events are monitored by an escalation clock. If an event does not occur within a prescribed period of time, an escalation action is executed. The exact timing and actions of an escalation depend on how your system is configured.

Url.Title: Task Response
Url.Abstract: Task Response If you or your team is assigned a task, you must respond to it within a prescribed amount of time. If you do not, an escalation notification displays as specified by your system configuration. When you are notified of a task response escalation:

Url.Title: Responding to a Task by Email
Url.Abstract: Responding to a Task by Email You can accept or reject a Task assignment by responding to it directly from the Task notification email in your email client.

Url.Title: Completing a Task
Url.Abstract: Completing a Task To be considered resolved, a task must have a status of completed or canceled. If a task is not resolved in a prescribed amount of time, an escalation notification displays as specified by your system configuration.

Url.Title: Canceling a Task
Url.Abstract: Canceling a Task You can cancel a task that is not completed. From the task toolbar, click Cancel. The Cancel window appears.

Url.Title: Workflow Instance
Url.Abstract: Workflow Instance If an object is part of a workflow (usually involving the approval process or a status progression), then a workflow appears under the Workflow Instance tab of a record.

Url.Title: Configuration Menu Index
Url.Abstract: Configuration Menu Index This topic lists the Settings menu items in the Configuration Console and the related documentation.

Url.Title: Business Objects
Url.Abstract: Business Objects A business object is defined by sets of metadata stored in a business object definition. Business objects are created through the administrator.

Url.Title: Using Business Objects
Url.Abstract: Using Business Objects Everything within HEAT is driven by business objects.

Url.Title: Using Fields
Url.Abstract: Using Fields A field is a container of information within a business object. Fields can reflect information that is typed or selected by the user. Sometimes field information is generated by the system.

Url.Title: Using Forms
Url.Abstract: Using Forms A form is a graphical view of record and field information. On a form, each field is represented by a field control and often a label. Forms can also have other components, such as images, to enhance their usability.

Url.Title: Form Controls
Url.Abstract: Form Controls A control is a form item that can be individually selected and manipulated. Text boxes, drop-down lists, buttons, labels, and images are all controls.

Url.Title: Related Objects Lists
Url.Abstract: Related Objects Lists This control allows contents from related objects to show on the Master Object form. You can configure additional operations of related items. Allowable operations included are: Add New, Edit, Delete, Link or Unlink. The administrator selects the fields from the related object that appear to users, defines the format, and specifies the sorting sequence of displayed objects. Specific formatting is provided for email, notes and text messages.

Url.Title: Other Form Controls
Url.Abstract: Other Form Controls Listed are the Other controls for business object forms.

Url.Title: Show Cell in Different Colors Based on Value
Url.Abstract: Show Cell in Different Colors Based on Value This topic describes how to colorize an incident record based on the value in the impact field.

Url.Title: How to Limit Attachment Size
Url.Abstract: How to Limit Attachment Size Administrators can limit the size and number of any attachments users can attach to a record. The attachment limit is set when designing the form from the Attachment form control.

Url.Title: Using Layouts
Url.Abstract: Using Layouts Layouts are what the user sees when viewing a workspace: a collection of forms, tabs, grids, and splitters that displays a parent record and its child records. The layout shows you a complete view of a parent record. The parent record appears as a form with its child records displayed under a series of tabs. Layouts differ from forms in that forms present the user with fields in which they can enter data for a specific record. Layouts generally show a list of records at the top part of the window, and a preview section of a selected record at the bottom.

Url.Title: Making Layouts Available to Users
Url.Abstract: Making Layouts Available to Users Layouts (the workspace buttons that appear at the top of a page) are available to users according to their logged in role.

Url.Title: Assigning Layouts (Workspaces) to Roles
Url.Abstract: Assigning Layouts (Workspaces) to Roles You can create a unique look for each role.

Url.Title: Data Rollup
Url.Abstract: Data Rollup The layout editor links data based on a mathematical concept called the transitive relationship. If a is related to b, and b is related to c, then a is also related to c. In the layout editor, you can display a grandchild object (c) in relation to the parent object (a) within a child panel grid.

Url.Title: Configuring Mobile Layouts
Url.Abstract: Configuring Mobile Layouts HEAT is supported on the Apple iPhone and iPad, enabling users such as service technicians and change managers to perform tasks in the system while away from their desks.

Url.Title: Toolbar Editor
Url.Abstract: The Toolbar Editor Use the toolbar editor to add, organize, delete, and customize toolbar items. Toolbar items include quick actions, commands, separators, and blank buttons. Each toolbar item (except separators) can contain additional menus.

Url.Title: Adding Toolbar Components
Url.Abstract: Adding Toolbar Components Within the toolbar editor, you see a palette with available buttons. You can filter the display to show special buttons, defined commands, and quick actions.

Url.Title: Using Grids
Url.Abstract: Using Grids A grid shows multiple records in a table view. Columns represent the fields for each record. Grids are defined within each business object, and are then viewed in a layout.

Url.Title: Default Grid Settings
Url.Abstract: Default Grid Settings Use the Grid Setting page to define the default number of rows (records) displayed in a dashboard and child panel grids. You can quickly change user interface and dashboard appears with this control.

Url.Title: Grid Highlights
Url.Abstract: Grid Highlights If you are an administrator, you can create custom styles to apply to grids. You can use these styles to highlight changes to individual records as they are listed in the grid when certain conditions apply. For example, you can have all unlicensed products appear in a list in a bold font with a red background. After creating a dynamic style, you can apply it to a field on a grid.

Url.Title: Formatting Rules
Url.Abstract: Formatting Rules Formatting rules are lines and colors that are used in grids. For example, you can show grids with alternating yellow rows or you can show grids with lines (borders) between each row.

Url.Title: Grid Style Usage Statistics
Url.Abstract: Grid Style Usage Statistics You can see the business objects to which grid styles have been applied. From the Configuration Console Main Menu, choose Grid Highlighter.

Url.Title: Highlight Certain Incidents
Url.Abstract: Highlight Certain Incidents This example explains how to highlight incidents in a grid where the incident or a child object has been modified by someone who is not the owner. This lets the owner quickly see where there is something they need to review.

Url.Title: Using Pick Lists
Url.Abstract: Using Pick Lists A Pick List is a list of values shown on a drop-down or combo-box. Pick lists supply other objects with field values and are stored as child objects in a relationship.

Url.Title: Using Validation Business Objects
Url.Abstract: Using Validation Business Objects A validation object is a business object list that is linked to another object, usually a pick list.

Url.Title: Adding Values to a Pick List
Url.Abstract: Adding Values to a Pick List Values can be added to a pick list from the business object. Validation list values can also be added through the Validation Business Objects page. See Add Validation List Values.

Url.Title: Configure Pick List for a Request Offering
Url.Abstract: Configure a Pick List for a Request Offering This example shows how to configure a pick list for a Request Offering.

Url.Title: Using Relationships
Url.Abstract: Using Relationships A business object relationship lets two business objects collaborate. More specifically, it lets the records included in the objects work together. In a relationship, business objects can belong to other business objects or simply be associated with other objects.

Url.Title: Using ERD
Url.Abstract: Using ERD You can view an Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) of some objects (ie. incident, change) from the ERD tab. This provides a high-level view of related objects.

Url.Title: Using Relationships in a Grid
Url.Abstract: Using Relationships in a Grid You can use direct relationships when designing a grid. (See Using Grids.) However, indirect or distant relationships don't work.

Url.Title: Using Business Rules
Url.Abstract: Using Business Rules Business rules occur as an extension of the activity on the client user interface. They interact with the client user interface causing values to be updated, related records to be created or updated, etc.

Url.Title: Overriding the Read-Only Rule
Url.Abstract: Overriding the Read-Only Rule You can override the read-only business rule.

Url.Title: Business Rule Examples
Url.Abstract: Business Rule Examples

Url.Title: Configure Object Search
Url.Abstract: Configure Object Search Content not yet available. Dragon.

Url.Title: Using Counters
Url.Abstract: Using Counters You can manage counters for existing business objects and set up counters for new business objects.

Url.Title: Using a Counter Name in an Initialization Rule
Url.Abstract: Using a Counter Name in an Initialization Rule Within the Configuration Console, choose Business Objects.

Url.Title: Business Object Examples
Url.Abstract: Business Object Examples These examples show how to configure business objects in various scenarios.

Url.Title: Templates
Url.Abstract: Templates Templates are designed to speed data entry in commonly completed fields in object forms. A template contains defined content for one or more fields in an object form. When a user applies the template to an object form, the system transfers the defined content into the object form.

Url.Title: Dashboards
Url.Abstract: Dashboards

Url.Title: The Dashboard Editor
Url.Abstract: About the Dashboard Editor The Dashboard Editor is where you configure your dashboards and create dashboard parts. From here you determine how dashboards are laid out.

Url.Title: Dashboard Examples
Url.Abstract: Dashboard Examples The following examples show how to use dashboards in various scenarios.

Url.Title: Data Logs
Url.Abstract: Logging You can create logs for various events. View Logs To view a log, log into the Configuration Console as administrator.

Url.Title: Configure Logging
Url.Abstract: Logging Configuration Each time you run a service, the system can create a log. HEAT includes a set of default services, but you can create additional services if needed. You must create your service before you can configure it for logging.

Url.Title: CMDB Baseline Log
Url.Abstract: CMDB Baseline Log The CMDB Baseline log is included by default and lists the baseline IDs for specific objects.

Url.Title: Integration Log
Url.Abstract: Integration Log The Integration log is included by default and lists data integration import jobs. See View the Data Integration Log - File Integration.

Url.Title: LDAP Import Log
Url.Abstract: LDAP Import Log The LDAP Import log is included by default and lists all imports executed through LDAP.

Url.Title: Transaction Audit Log
Url.Abstract: Transaction Audit Log The Transaction Audit log lists create, update, and delete events that are enabled per business object class. It also allows views of business object details to be logged. View logging is enabled per form or form-view.

Url.Title: Date, Time, and Time Zones
Url.Abstract: Date, Time, and Timezones You can specify which timezone options appear whenever you encounter a Date and Time control on a form.

Url.Title: Timezones
Url.Abstract: Timezones You can choose which timezones to show within HEAT and in what order the timezone appear in a list. All major world timezones have been included in HEAT, but you can create a timezone that meets your specific needs.

Url.Title: Time Zone Examples
Url.Abstract: Timezone Examples

Url.Title: Configuring Date and Time Fields
Url.Abstract: Configuring Date and Time Fields You can configure a field to present the date and time of a specific timezone, which the users can select within a form. For example, if your server is in Germany but your users are in Australia, the server date might be difficult to understand or cumbersome to use. You can create a DateTime business object that corresponds to the timezone of the user and place it on a form. The users will have the option to choose the server date and time or the local date and time.

Url.Title: The Timezone Object
Url.Abstract: The Timezone Object This topics lists the default definitions of the Timezone (FRS_Timezone) object.

Url.Title: Escalations
Url.Abstract: Escalations An escalation clock monitors various HEAT events. If an event does not occur in a prescribed period, HEAT executes an escalation action of some type. The exact timing and actions of an escalation depend on how you configure the escalation as described in this section.

Url.Title: Creating an Escalation
Url.Abstract: Creating an Escalation

Url.Title: Escalation Exceptions
Url.Abstract: Escalation Exceptions You can define exceptions to the escalation lifecycle based on field values within the escalation. You can next exceptions within other exceptions.

Url.Title: Importing & Exporting Data
Url.Abstract: Importing and Exporting Data The HEAT architecture easily connects to and integrates with data sources and simplifies the importation of external data from other web services.

Url.Title: Configuring Data Integration
Url.Abstract: Import SCCM, manual, files. Overall Procedures, connecting to sources, object and field mapping.

Url.Title: Data Import
Url.Abstract: Data Import This option enables you to import data from a predefined source into the HEATSM database.

Url.Title: Data Import Configuration
Url.Abstract: Data Import Configuration You can import files up to 500 MB using an FTP or File connection. Enter your information into the fields.

Url.Title: SCCM Configuration
Url.Abstract: SCCM Configuration You can import data from your Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) database into a HEAT Configuration Management Database (CMDB). This is a one-way import of data. Once you have mapped the fields, you can import data on a scheduled basis.

Url.Title: Field Mapping
Url.Abstract: Field Mapping The asset identifiers and their mapped field are stored in the Asset Data Mapping form. This form is only available to administrators by default.

Url.Title: Schedule Manager
Url.Abstract: Schedule Manager This option does not appear if you select the manual option in the Connection Manager window.

Url.Title: Review & Publish
Url.Abstract: Review and Publish You have three options to review or publish your data:

Url.Title: Run Program - Remote Host
Url.Abstract: Run Program - Remote Host Remote connections are set up to connect to remote computers using Microsoft Windows remote management protocol. Run program is a way to execute a windows application from the HEAT platform. This is useful when you need to execute a program to accomplish some task that cannot be automated within HEAT itself. Some examples might include running PowerShell scripts to manage Active Directory user passwords, importing information from HEAT into a third party application, or running an XSL transformation using msxsl.exe.

Url.Title: Reset a Password using Run Program
Url.Abstract: Reset a Password Using Run Program This example shows how to create a quick action that resets a password when a user submits a service request.

Url.Title: Start or Stop a Service using Run Program
Url.Abstract: Start or Stop a Service Using Run Program This example shows how to create a quick action that starts or stops a service.

Url.Title: Run Program History
Url.Abstract: Run Program History The Run Program/Export History page lists each time the run program export action has been run and the result. It is a convenient way for you to determine if your exports are working.

Url.Title: Data Export
