Url.Abstract: Data Export This integration option enables you to export data on a scheduled basis. Data export connections are set up to connect to FTP or a shared network folder as a saving location for Export Data Quick Action quick action.

Url.Title: Integration Status and History
Url.Abstract: Integration Status and History You can view the status of your data import and cancel a running import.

Url.Title: LDAP Settings
Url.Abstract: LDAP Settings HEAT supports the use of LDAP, including Active Directory as well as other LDAP servers that implement LDAP .

Url.Title: Manually Running an Activated Connection
Url.Abstract: Manually Running an Activated Connection Once a connection has been activated, it runs at the scheduled time. However, you can manually run the import connection at any time.

Url.Title: Troubleshooting Data Integration
Url.Abstract: Troubleshooting Data Integration The fastest way to spot errors is to look at the integration log. See View the Data Integration Log - File Integration and View the Integration Log - SCCM on how to use this feature.

Url.Title: Scheduling
Url.Abstract: Scheduling HEAT comes with various tools to enable you to run reports and functions at regular scheduled intervals. This section describes those tools.

Url.Title: Schedule Entry
Url.Abstract: Schedule Entry The Schedule Entry workspace enables you to create a variety of schedules to be used in different functions, such as using timezones within the time object. These schedules appear in a drop-down list within corresponding workspaces. The schedule must be created in Schedule Entry before it will appear in other places.

Url.Title: Default Schedules
Url.Abstract: Default Schedules The following schedules are included in HEAT by default, and can be modified to your circumstances.

Url.Title: Security
Url.Abstract: Application Security To ensure data segregation, each tenant organization is assigned its own secure database within the HEAT Data Center.

Url.Title: Authorization
Url.Abstract: Authorization HEAT employs role-based security to add security restrictions at the following levels:

Url.Title: Security Examples
Url.Abstract: Security Examples

Url.Title: Authentication
Url.Abstract: Authentication When logging into the HEAT application, the system can enforce authentication through internal or external means. These are specified by checking one or both of the following checkboxes when creating an employee account:

Url.Title: Setting up Authentication
Url.Abstract: Setting up Authentication

Url.Title: Authentication Providers
Url.Abstract: Authentication Providers Before setting up the authentication providers, make sure you have configured your ADFS/SAML server and downloaded the certificate.

Url.Title: Authentication Configuration
Url.Abstract: Authentication Configuration

Url.Title: LDAP Synchronization
Url.Abstract: LDAP Synchronization If you enable external authentication, you must synchronize employee profiles from the LDAP directory server. For more information on LDAP synchronization, see LDAP Settings.

Url.Title: Direct AD Authentication
Url.Abstract: Direct AD Authentication This topic describes how to configure HEAT AD authentication using Windows Integrated Security (WIS).

Url.Title: Encryption Keys
Url.Abstract: Encryption Keys The Encryption Key Workspace The Public Key Workspace Encryption is a process that makes information unreadable by anyone except those who have a key that allows them to change the information to its original, readable form. Encryption allows users to securely protect sensitive data that they do not want others to access, such as passwords, social security numbers, and so on.

Url.Title: Workflows
Url.Abstract: Workflows A business process is a set of activities that performs a specific task. A workflow is a type of business process, typically structured in HEAT to handle support tickets and escalations that can be long running. Workflows can be triggered by a user action, a time-based event, or another business process.

Url.Title: Using Workflows
Url.Abstract: Using Workflows Workflows are defined using the Workflow Designer. The Workflow Designer is a graphical tool that allows you to arrange blocks of activities using a drag-and-drop interface to create workflows. The Workflow Engine executes the activities created within the Workflow Designer. Workflows are distinguished by the following characteristics:

Url.Title: Validating Workflows
Url.Abstract: Validating Workflows The Validation Engine validates your workflow during any point of assembly. To validate the workflow, either click Validate under the Validation tab, or check Validate before saving from the toolbar to perform the validation each time you save the workflow.

Url.Title: Importing and Exporting a Workflow
Url.Abstract: Importing and Exporting a Workflow

Url.Title: Using Users or Groups as Pick List Values in the Get Approval Block
Url.Abstract: Using Users or Groups as Pick List Values in the Get Approval Block When designing the Get Approval block, ensure the picklist you select as a value for the user or contact group (who gets the approval notification) has a stored value that is an unique identifier for the user or contact group.

Url.Title: Define an Approval Block for the Service Request Business Object
Url.Abstract: Define an Approval Block for the Service Request Business Object Determine Approver Field Within the Configuration Console, click Business Objects, then select ServiceRequest. The Service Request Details page appears.

Url.Title: Using Task Status with WaitForChild
Url.Abstract: Using Task Status with WaitForChild This example shows how to set up a workflow that waits for multiple tasks to be Completed before continuing.

Url.Title: Cancel a Workflow Awaiting Approval
Url.Abstract: Cancel a Workflow Awaiting Approval You can cancel a request, change, incident, or other object while it is in Pending Approval state.

Url.Title: WaitForChild Block Does Not Execute
Url.Abstract: WaitForChild Block Does Not Execute Sometimes it appears the WaitForChild workflow block does not execute. This can happen if a child business object does not meet the needed criteria.

Url.Title: Module Configuration
Url.Abstract: Module Configuration System Overview System Module Configuration Overview The FrontRange HEAT process uses the Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) in its design for working with business objects and managing service support and delivery. HEAT includes some additional FrontRange service support processes and management not specified by ITIL.

Url.Title: Change Management
Url.Abstract: Change Management Change Management is the process of managing changes in a controlled, efficient, and standardized way with the goal of minimizing business risk and maintaining service continuity. Change Management assesses any impact or potential risk a proposed change could have on your organization before it is introduced.

Url.Title: Change Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Change Lifecycle The following diagram illustrates the lifecycle of a typical change request: Change Lifecycle

Url.Title: Configure the Change Calendar
Url.Abstract: Configure the Change Calendar

Url.Title: Change Object Reference
Url.Abstract: Change Object Reference Listed below are the default definitions of the change object.

Url.Title: The Change Approval Workflow
Url.Abstract: The Change Approval Workflow This section describes the default change approval workflow. See Using Workflows for information on modifying workflows.

Url.Title: Change Risk Reference
Url.Abstract: Change Risk Reference

Url.Title: Configuration Management
Url.Abstract: Configuration Management ITIL defines a Configuration as a group of Configuration Items (CIs) working together to deliver an IT Service, or a recognizable part of an IT Service. Configuration is also used to describe the parameter settings for one or more CIs.

Url.Title: Incident Management
Url.Abstract: Incident Management An incident is defined by ITIL as any break in the standard operation of a service that causes or might cause an interruption or reduction in the quality of that service. The goal of incident Management is to restore normal service as quickly as possible when IT service has been disrupted, and to make sure that business operations are functioning normally. The definition of normal service is agreed to in Service Level Agreements (SLAs) with the customers of your organization.

Url.Title: Incident Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Incident Lifecycle The following diagram illustrates the lifecycle of an incident. Incident lifecycle The following diagram show the various stages of an incident, including response and resolution times.

Url.Title: Incident Object Reference
Url.Abstract: Incident Object The following table lists the default definitions of the incident object.

Url.Title: Inventory Management
Url.Abstract: Inventory Management Inventory Management is the discovery and auditing of assets or configuration items used in the organization and making sure that they are in the configuration management database (or CMDB). After these configuration items are discovered and audited, Configuration Management maintains information about configuration items required to deliver an IT service, including their relationships.

Url.Title: Inventory Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Inventory Lifecycle The Inventory Management lifecycle is generally automatic once configured. Inventory Management lifecycle

Url.Title: How Discovery and Inventory Auditing work
Url.Abstract: How Discovery and Inventory Auditing Work The following diagram illustrates how the different components involved in Inventory Management communicate with each other:

Url.Title: Using Inventory Discovery and Auditing
Url.Abstract: Using Inventory Discovery and Auditing All main inventory audit tasks are restricted to the Inventory Manager role.

Url.Title: HEAT Discovery Asset Management
Url.Abstract: HEAT Discovery Asset Management The HEAT Discovery page enables you to deploy Discovery in various ways.

Url.Title: Deploying Agents to Other Computers
Url.Abstract: Deploying Agents to Other Computers You need to deploy agents to computers in order to get the most comprehensive and detailed audit, but remote scan via WMI is also an alternative (see About Running Agentless Audits).

Url.Title: Viewing and Managing Asset Data
Url.Abstract: Viewing and Managing Asset Data The Asset Data Mapping workspace controls how incoming asset data gets processed by the Asset Processor and to which business object this data maps.

Url.Title: Configuring DSM
Url.Abstract: Configuring the DSM This section contains an overview of HEAT–DSM integration concepts. The HEAT–DSM integration makes DSM software lifecycle management tools available in the HEAT application.

Url.Title: Configuring the DSM Environment
Url.Abstract: Configuring the DSM Environment in HEAT To establish the initial HEAT–DSM environment, do the following:

Url.Title: Performing Ongoing Maintenance
Url.Abstract: Performing Ongoing Maintenance After the HEAT–DSM environment is configured, perform ongoing maintenance to address the following scenarios.

Url.Title: DSM Integration
Url.Abstract: DSM Integration You can view the user DSM URL and client authentication key if you have administrator privileges.

Url.Title: Fields Collected by Agent and Agentless Scans
Url.Abstract: Fields Collected by Agent and Agentless Scans Data from the source fields (first column) are automatically mapped to the target fields (second column) in HEAT Cloud.

Url.Title: Knowledge Management
Url.Abstract: Knowledge Management ITIL defines Knowledge Management as the one central process responsible for providing knowledge to all other IT Service Management processes. In HEAT, Knowledge works with incident Management and Problem Management and is a powerful feature in the Self Service application.

Url.Title: Knowledge Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Knowledge Lifecycle The following diagram shows the typical process for a Knowledge article: Knowledge Lifecycle

Url.Title: Knowledge Object Reference
Url.Abstract: Knowledge Object The default definitions of the knowledge object are.

Url.Title: Problem Management
Url.Abstract: Problem Management ITIL defines Problem Management as a process designed to eliminate recurring incidents from the IT Infrastructure. A problem is identified by multiple incidents exhibiting common symptoms or a single incident with no known cause.

Url.Title: Problem Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Problem Lifecycle A typical problem detection, reporting, and recovery life cycle is shown: Problem Lifecycle

Url.Title: Problem Object Reference
Url.Abstract: Problem Object The following sections describe the default problem business objects.

Url.Title: Release Management
Url.Abstract: Release Management Release Management is responsible for designing, testing, and installing defined changes in the live environment. While Change Management manages the process of change, Release Management manages the deployment of those Configuration Items (CIs) that are implemented by Change Management. A Release consists of rolling out new or updated software or hardware (Configuration Items) required to implement approved changes.The implementation of new hardware or software releases combine the controlled process of Configuration Management with the communication and preparation of Change Management. A Release is thus initiated as part of the Change Management process and works with Configuration Management.

Url.Title: Release Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Release Lifecycle Release lifecycle Major (created without Templates), Minor, and Emergency Releases are not included in the approval workflow. Milestones can be created using quick actions, but they are not subject to the approval workflow. The following diagram shows the states of a Release that is not Major (and not created using a Template):

Url.Title: Service Catalog Management
Url.Abstract: Service Catalog Management The Service Catalog is how customers can order products and services from your organization. You control the customer experience within the Service Catalog framework, defining for each item an image, description, price, other fields, and workflow.

Url.Title: Service Request Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Service Request Lifecycle Service Request lifecycle

Url.Title: Configuring Offering Access
Url.Abstract: Configuring Offering Access You can determine who can access and edit a request item when you publish a request offering.

Url.Title: Configuring the List Control
Url.Abstract: Configuring the List Control Request Offering - Item Configuration Editor Place the List Onto the Form

Url.Title: Configuring Categories
Url.Abstract: Configuring Categories When creating a request offering, you assign it to a category. When users view the Service Catalog, they can browse services offered according to this category.

Url.Title: Configuring Editable and Cancellable Service Requests
Url.Abstract: Configuring Editable and Cancellable Service Requests You can allow users to edit or cancel specific service requests. You can also configure service requests to NOT be editable or cancellable beyond a certain point (for example, after approval or notification). Service requests that are set to a status of cancelled, closed, or fulfilled are by default not cancellable or editable.

Url.Title: Service Portfolio
Url.Abstract: Service Portfolio The Service Portfolio represents a complete list of the services managed by the service provider. It contains present contractual commitments, new service development, and retired services.

Url.Title: Default Catalog Offerings
Url.Abstract: Default Catalog Offerings

Url.Title: Service Level Management
Url.Abstract: Service Level Management Request offerings are provided by an organization to serve customers; they are used to help classify incidents and specific services within the system. Descriptions of the supported service offering is documented with the CI.Service object. It is intended to classify incidents as they are recorded and to provide a 360 degree view of the request offering, including Service Level Agreements and supporting CI-Assets. It also includes a historical view of incident, problem and changes that have been reported against the request offering.

Url.Title: Service Level Management Lifecycle
Url.Abstract: Service Level Management Lifecycle The following process is recommended in configuring Self Service and the Service Catalog. Use the Service Owner or administrator role.

Url.Title: Service Request Object Reference
Url.Abstract: Service Request Object This section lists the default definitions of the service request object.

Url.Title: Setting Up Surveys
Url.Abstract: Setting Up Surveys Customer surveys measure customer satisfaction with the various departments in your organization. Surveys are published over the web, and distributed by email. When opened, they appear in a new browser window.

Url.Title: Sending Surveys
Url.Abstract: Sending Surveys Surveys are sent automatically using a business rule which invokes a Send Email quick action. The default business rule Send Survey upon Incident Closure is included in HEAT. The email contains a link to the survey stored in the HEAT database.

Url.Title: Viewing Survey Results
Url.Abstract: Viewing Survey Results Viewing, monitoring, and tracking survey statistics is an important task for a Service Desk Manager. Customer feedback in the form of survey responses are a valuable source of data collection for gathering metrics on the effectiveness of the Service Desk in responding to and resolving customer incidents.

Url.Title: Using the Score Card
Url.Abstract: Using the Score Card You can easily determine the level of customer satisfaction from a number of factors within the score card.

Url.Title: Configuring Survey Frequency
Url.Abstract: Configuring Survey Frequency

Url.Title: Survey Objects Reference
Url.Abstract: Survey Objects The following table contains the default survey business objects.

Url.Title: Outage Log
Url.Abstract: Outage Log The Outage Log captures information on a service outage and is part of the Availability Management process. Each time you have an outage, record it here. The Availability Report deducts this time from the availability.

Url.Title: Voice Configuration
Url.Abstract: Voice Configuration Topics In This Section

Url.Title: Configuring Communicator Settings
Url.Abstract: Configuring Communicator Settings Communicator settings are configured by default. However, you must enter or verify your user information and phone extension.

Url.Title: Configuring Voice Integration
Url.Abstract: Configuring Voice Integration To enable a Start IPCM Voice Activity quick action, you must first configure HEAT to connect to IPCM.

Url.Title: Configuring Agent Voice Settings
Url.Abstract: Configuring Agent Voice Settings After configuring voice at the group level, you can customize at the individual agent level.

Url.Title: Configuring Group Voice
Url.Abstract: Configuring Group Voice You can configure agent groups for the purpose of organizing agents and specifying group settings. You can also configure skill groups for the purpose of matching agents with skills. After you configure agents at the group level, you can override the group settings at the agent level.

Url.Title: Universal Worklist
Url.Abstract: Universal Worklist The universal worklist feature enables you to simultaneously view worklists from multiple tenants. A worklist is a list of items (usually issues, changes, or problems) and is typically the result of a saved search.

Url.Title: Slave Tenants
Url.Abstract: Slave Tenants This workspace defines slave tenants to be used with the universal worklist. See Universal Worklist.

Url.Title: Web API
Url.Abstract: HEAT Web API The HEAT web API module is a framework with sample methods that can be used to integrate external web applications with Self Service and Service Catalog. Developers can retrieve data from the HEAT database and publish navigation links to specific HEAT application pages. It can also offer pass-through authentication for external portal users.

Url.Title: Cloud Connect API
Url.Abstract: Cloud Connect API The following methods have been added to HEAT web services API to enable manipulation of service requests.

Url.Title: API Keys
Url.Abstract: API Keys You can link user groups to one or more API (application programming interface) keys, which are codes that authenticate access and can be used to track API usage. API keys are not tied to user sessions with expiration times.

Url.Title: Defining Your Organization
Url.Abstract: Defining Your Organization Configure these features to define your organization:

Url.Title: Organization Chart
Url.Abstract: Organization Chart The Org Unit Workspace Organizations, such as companies, are divided into separate groups, referred as organizational units. Use an organizational unit hierarchy to apply structure to your organization. Creating a parent-child structure of organization units can prove useful for data segregation and organizational security.

Url.Title: Supporting Organizations
Url.Abstract: Supporting Organizations

Url.Title: License Tracking
Url.Abstract: License Tracking HEAT allows both named and concurrent user license types. This data is based on content in the Logon_History object.

Url.Title: Tracking Named Users
Url.Abstract: Tracking Named Users Select Is Named User for each user to whom you are assigning a named user license. If a user is not specified as a named user, the user is treated as a concurrent user.

Url.Title: Viewing the License Usage Report
Url.Abstract: Viewing the License Usage Report Within the Configuration Console Main Menu, choose Report Editor. The system displays a list of reports.

Url.Title: LogonHistory API
Url.Abstract: LogonHistory API When a user logs out, the system sets the Logout Type field for the LogonHistory object to explicit.

Url.Title: Planning Your Deployment
Url.Abstract: Planning Your Deployment Before you deploy HEAT, it is important to map out your HEAT structure. You need to plan your:

Url.Title: Hardware and Software Requirements
Url.Abstract: Hardware and Software Requirements

Url.Title: Linux/Unix Support
Url.Abstract: Linux/Unix Support Linux and Unix drivers are available for download from our support site. You must be a registered user to obtain these files.

Url.Title: Deployment Sequence
Url.Abstract: Deployment Sequence Use the following basic checklist when planning your HEAT deployment:

Url.Title: Setting Up the Application
Url.Abstract: Setting Up the Application You can initially set up your modules in HEAT on the Application Setup page (formerly known as Process Wizard). After initial setup, you can access various parts of Application Setup within the Configuration Console to modify your settings.

Url.Title: Account Information
Url.Abstract: Account Information The Your Account wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Enter basic information about the tenant account. Here is where you set the defaults to use throughout HEAT, including, including your default time zone and currency. This information is also available under Settings > Configure > Organization Profile.

Url.Title: Customer Information
Url.Abstract: Customer Information The Customer Information wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to add internal customers or external customers who have purchased a product or service from your company and require support.

Url.Title: The Incident Management Wizard
Url.Abstract: The Incident Management Wizard The Incident Management wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to define how your Service Desk will manage incidents.

Url.Title: Service Desk Configuration
Url.Abstract: Service Desk Configuration The Service Desk Configuration wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to define the access and workflow for information collected and acted upon by your company's service desk.

Url.Title: The Style Editor
Url.Abstract: The Style Editor Administrators can create custom background and font colors within the Style Editor page. You can experiment with various color combinations before publishing to your Service Desk.

Url.Title: The Change Management Wizard
Url.Abstract: The Change Management Wizard The Change Management wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to customize how the Service Desk handles the change management process.

Url.Title: The Request Management Wizard
Url.Abstract: The Request Management Wizard The Request Management wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to customize how the Service Desk will handle request management processes.

Url.Title: Self Service Configuration
Url.Abstract: Self Service Configuration The Self Service Configuration wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to define the display of the Self Service module and to add users who can access the module. You can also access these features from the Configuration Console Home page.

Url.Title: Home Page
Url.Abstract: Home Page Select the default set of dashboard parts to appear to users upon logging into the Self Service module.

Url.Title: Branding
Url.Abstract: Branding The Branding options only apply to the Self Service role. You can designate what Self Service users see, such as Logo or workspace items.

Url.Title: Tabs
Url.Abstract: Tabs Select the pages (user interfaces) to appear to Self Service users upon logging in. Within the Configuration Console Main Menu, choose Self Service. The Self Service configuration page appears.

Url.Title: Video: Changing Tab Order
Url.Abstract: Video: Changing Tab Order

Url.Title: Users
Url.Abstract: Users The Users wizard is part of the Application Setup Page. Use this wizard to add users to the system and to assign them to specific roles. A user must be assigned at least one role in order to log into the HEAT system. You can also add and modify users from the Settings menu. Go to Configure > Users and Permissions > Users.

Url.Title: About Roles
Url.Abstract: About Roles The Role Workspace The system assigned at least one role to all HEAT users of the type employee. Users can have multiple roles. The system uses roles to define responsibilities for the users as they work within the application.

Url.Title: Administrator Tasks
Url.Abstract: Administrator Tasks Administrators manage the overall administration of the HEAT application and monitor its operational health. Administrators have access to all modules and configuration workspaces.

Url.Title: Change Roles
Url.Abstract: Change Roles The following roles are most relevant to the Change workspace:

Url.Title: Change Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Change Manager Tasks Change Managers ensure that changes are introduced into the organization with minimum disruption to existing services. Change Managers can initiate a change request, but usually they manage changes through their lifecycles.

Url.Title: Configuration Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Configuration Manager Tasks Configuration Managers are responsible for the configuration management process and the Configuration Management Database (CMDB). They maintain all configuration items in the CMDB.

Url.Title: Executive Tasks
Url.Abstract: Executive Role The HEAT system provides the Executive role to provide executives the ability to see the available incidents, problems, changes, and releases in the system.

Url.Title: Guest Tasks
Url.Abstract: Guest Role The Guest role is a generic role that allows guest users to log into the system. The administrator customizes the top level tabs and object permissions for the Guest role.

Url.Title: Inventory Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Inventory Manager Role Inventory Managers install the gateway software component for asset tracking purposes and conduct audits of the network software and configuration for compliance tracking purposes.

Url.Title: Knowledge Management Roles
Url.Abstract: Knowledge Management Roles

Url.Title: Knowledge Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Knowledge Manager Tasks Knowledge Managers ensure that knowledge is stored and shared among the various IT processes, gather and analyze information and knowledge, and improve efficiency by reducing the need to rediscover knowledge.

Url.Title: License Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: License Manager Tasks License Managers maintain and track licenses for the software in your organization and ensure compliance with the licensing requirements of the manufacturer.

Url.Title: Problem Management Roles
Url.Abstract: Problem Management Roles The following users typically work with Problem Management: Problem Manager Problem Managers are responsible for the following:

Url.Title: Problem Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Problem Manager Tasks Problem Managers research the root causes of incidents, make temporary solutions (workarounds) available, and develop final solutions for known errors. Problem Managers engage in proactive problem management by analyzing trends or historical data of incidents and services.

Url.Title: Release Management Roles
Url.Abstract: Release Management Roles The following users typically work with Release Management: Release Manager Release Managers are responsible for creating, managing, and executing all aspects of a release, including preplanning, testing, documentation, training, and so on.

Url.Title: Release Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Release Manager Tasks Release Managers implement changes to ensure that they are carried out effectively and safely, and verified with minimum impact and risk to the organization.

Url.Title: Report Manager Tasks
Url.Abstract: Report Manager Tasks Report Managers do the following: The default workspaces for the Report Manager are:

Url.Title: Self Service Tasks
Url.Abstract: Self Service Tasks Self Service users use the Self Service workspace to request services and to report failures. Self Service users can also access FAQs, announcements, and knowledge center articles to try to resolve issues themselves. When a Self Service user submits an incident or a service request, the system logs it with the Service Desk, where a Service Desk Analyst begins processing it. Users can use the Self Service workspace to track the progress of an incident, add more information, and communicate with a Service Desk Analyst while the incident or the service request is being worked on.

Url.Title: Service Request Roles
Url.Abstract: Service Request Roles Service Desk Analyst (SDA) Service Desk Analysts typically help Self Service users if they need to create, manage, and update service requests. They can do the following:

Url.Title: Service Desk Analyst (SDA) Tasks
Url.Abstract: Service Desk Analyst Tasks Service Desk Analysts resolve incidents reported by users. Service Desk Analysts usually provide the initial point of contact with the customer. During the incident management process, Service Desk Analysts work with other specialists, vendors, and technicians to resolve incidents for the users.

Url.Title: Service Desk Manager (SDM) Tasks
Url.Abstract: Service Desk Manager Tasks Service Desk Managers are responsible for effectively managing the Service Desk and incident management process. Service Desk Managers oversee Service Desk Analysts as they resolve incidents and fulfill service requests.

Url.Title: Service Owner Tasks
Url.Abstract: Service Owner Tasks Service Owners create new services and make them available for creating request offerings (or request items that are available in the Service Catalog). After configuring the request offering, Service Owners define service level packages for these offerings.

Url.Title: Using Employees
Url.Abstract: Using Employees The Employee Workspace User accounts include general information (login and role information) and extended information (personal information).

Url.Title: Employment Type
Url.Abstract: Employment Type The Employment Type workspace enables you to define various types of employees. The default types are:

Url.Title: Using External Contacts
Url.Abstract: Using External Contacts You can view external users within the External Contact workspace.

Url.Title: Using the Contact Store
Url.Abstract: Using the Contact Store The Contact Store Workspace The Contact Store workspace is a list of all users: employees and external contacts.

Url.Title: Using Teams
Url.Abstract: Using Teams The Standard User Team Workspace Teams are pools of employees who can be assigned tasks within HEAT, such as Advisory or Review boards. An employee cannot be assigned a task without being part of a team.

Url.Title: Team Costing
Url.Abstract: Team Costing You can view and track transactional costs for a single service request, incident, change, problem, or release, or view the costing information in a report.

Url.Title: Using Departments
Url.Abstract: Using Departments The Departments list can categorize users according to a department within an organization, such as IT or Marketing. You can use Departments to assign specific Employee users as the approver in the Get Approval Workflow Block block in

Url.Title: Using Contact Groups
Url.Abstract: Using Contact Groups You can manage the groups associated with this employee account. A group is made up of one or more employees who are spprovers or decision-makers in the approval process. Common workflows requiring approvals include change requests and Knowledge Management.

Url.Title: Give an SDA Access to Assigned Incidents
Url.Abstract: Give an SDA Access to Assigned Incidents At minimum, a Service Desk Analyst should be able to view and update his assigned incidents (as specified in the Owner field on the incident form.)

Url.Title: Give an SDM Access to Incidents for an OU
Url.Abstract: Give an SDM Access to Incidents for an Organizational Unit An example of applying organizational unit restrictions on a hierarchical level is to allow a Service Desk Manager to update and view incidents created within the organizational unit, either by himself or by subordinates:

Url.Title: Give an SDA Access to Incidents Assigned to an OU
Url.Abstract: Give an SDA Access to Incidents Assigned to an OU In this case, the Service Desk Analyst should be able to begin work on an incident which is in the unassigned queue for his organizational unit (My Team). At the same time, the SDA should be able to view incidents which are assigned to other members of the team without being able to update them.

Url.Title: Give Self Service Access to Submitted Incidents
Url.Abstract: Give Self Service Access to Submitted Incidents Self Service users will want access to any incidents which they have submitted to the Service Desk for tracking purposes. You can restrict incident access by the Customer Name and/or Reported By fields.

Url.Title: Submit a Request on Behalf of a Customer
Url.Abstract: Submit a Request on Behalf of a Customer You can create a request on behalf of an external customer and create a relationship between the customer and the request.

Url.Title: Review & Finish
Url.Abstract: Review and Finish The Review and Finish page of the Application Setup Page shows the parts you have set up.

Url.Title: Currencies
Url.Abstract: Currencies You can define monetary denominations throughout the HEAT application. For example, you can designate the costs of your service requests in a specific currency, such as USD or Euros. The service request page does not show a specific currency symbol, but only the number value. However, the pricing is calculated based on the currency you specify.

Url.Title: Defining Global Constants
Url.Abstract: Defining Global Constants Define values to be referenced throughout a tenant from the Global Constants page.

Url.Title: Default Global Constants
Url.Abstract: Default Global Constants The following global constants are used throughout HEAT. See Defining Global Constants on how to create a global constant.

Url.Title: Using the Business Object Uploader
Url.Abstract: Using the Business Object Uploader If you have an existing set of business objects upon installing the HEAT tenant, you can import them into the HEAT application using the Business Object Uploader tool. The tool communicates with the HEAT application server using public web services to facilitate user logins, population of dataentry forms, and the upload of business object data.

Url.Title: Bulk Upload Configuration
Url.Abstract: Bulk Upload Configuration The HEAT system provides two tools for uploading business objects: the Bulk Uploader, which uses a web client, and the Business Object Uploader. The Business Object Uploader tool is a legacy desktop client. See Using the Business Object Uploader for information about using this tool.

Url.Title: My Items
Url.Abstract: My Items My Items is a ways for Self Service users to track their service requests and issues. They can access their list of items from their Home page in the My Items pane, or from the My Items workspace.

Url.Title: Adding a Custom Status Value to My Items
Url.Abstract: Adding a Custom Status Value to My Items By default, the My Items table in Self Service is configured to show incident, Service Request, and Approval records. As such, the values for the MyItem status object contains statuses from the incident, Service Request, and Approval business objects.

Url.Title: ClipboardData Plugin
Url.Abstract: ClipboardData Plugin Premise Users Only The clipboard plugin enable users to copy and paste text between applications. Administrators can install the plugin on a server and it installs silently to clients.

Url.Title: Setting Up Email
Url.Abstract: Setting Up Email Users can create incidents and other business objects (such as problems, changes, and knowledge articles) by email. By default, an object to create an incident using email comes with HEAT. Otherwise, you must create an inbox for each business object and you must provide users with a template.

Url.Title: Email Processing
Url.Abstract: Email Processing When a user sends an email to the inbox email address, the business object record (incident, problem, knowledge, or change) is automatically created. This section describes how these emails are processed within the application.

Url.Title: SolarWinds
Url.Abstract: Integrating with the SolarWinds Log & Event Manager You can easily integrate the SolarWinds Log & Event Manager, an event management and monitoring tool, with HEAT. Use the HEAT Email Listener feature, available with HEAT out-of-the-box, to perform the integration.

Url.Title: Email Servers
Url.Abstract: Email Servers The configuration for the email service provider is stored as a service business object in the HEAT management database, while tenant-specific configurations are stored within each tenant database.

Url.Title: Creating an Inbox
Url.Abstract: Creating an Inbox

Url.Title: Creating an Outbox
Url.Abstract: Creating an Outbox An outbox is the server that handles the outgoing emails. Each mail host has one server performing this function.

Url.Title: The Address Book
Url.Abstract: The Address Book The address book enables you to select multiple email recipients or senders without having to enter their individual full email addresses. It automatically obtains names and email addresses from the Employee and ExternalContact business objects.

Url.Title: Using Email
Url.Abstract: Using Email This section describes how to use email within HEAT.

Url.Title: Email Examples
Url.Abstract: Email Examples

Url.Title: Process an Email Based on Incident Status
Url.Abstract: Process an Email Based on Incident Status This example shows you how to create a quick action that changes the status of an incident from resolved to active whenever an email is received. There are two phases to this procedure: first create a quick action (to update the incident to active), then map the resolved status (for an incident) to the quick action.

Url.Title: Update a Service Request via Email
Url.Abstract: Update a Service Request via Email Service request records cannot be created from incoming emails; they can only be updated from incoming emails.

Url.Title: Create or Link Objects via Email
Url.Abstract: Create or Link Objects via Email Configure this option after you have created and saved an inbox. You can set up inbound emails to create an employee record or link to an employee record, or you can create an object record that is associated to the incident business object record without creating an employee record.

Url.Title: Send an Email with an Image
Url.Abstract: Send an Email with an Image Users can send an email to create a record (such as an incident) and include an embedded image.

Url.Title: Text is Double-Spaced Using Copy and Paste
Url.Abstract: Text is Double-Spaced Using Copy and Paste When you copy and paste an email from Outlook into a multi-line HTML field, the lines become double-spaced. This occurs because Outlook inserts a non-breaking space ( ) into each empty line. This issue is also browser dependent, as it occurs when using Firefox or Chrome, but not Internet Explorer.

Url.Title: Communication Manager
Url.Abstract: Communication Manager You can view all quick actions and workflows that use the Send Email Quick Action with the Communication Manager. This is also where you can create templates to use in the updated Get Approval Workflow Block.

Url.Title: Setting Up Hours of Operation
Url.Abstract: Setting Up Hours of Operation The Business Hours page enables you to define the operational calendar for your company, including daily hours and schedules. For example, you can determine the response time for a technician to an incident or execute a business rule that escalates a call that has been open for a number of hours.

Url.Title: Create an Hours of Operation Field
Url.Abstract: Create an Hours of Operation Field This example shows how to create a field to hold Hours of Operation. You can create a field to contain a value for Hours of Operation to add to a form for any and each business object.

Url.Title: About Localization
Url.Abstract: About Localization Administrators have many areas in which to localize the application to serve international customers.

Url.Title: Setting up Languages
Url.Abstract: Setting up Languages You can set the languages available for your users from the Languages page in the Configuration Console.

Url.Title: Using the Translation Tool
Url.Abstract: Using the Translation Tool HEAT provides a translation tool that lets you customize the text strings used in Self Service for each supported locale. You can use the translation tool to do the following:

Url.Title: Translating Label Expressions
Url.Abstract: Translating Label Expressions You can translate labels, including form headers, using the Local function. The localization tool finds the fields marked Is Localizable and matches them with their corresponding localized values.

Url.Title: Translating Self Service Templates
Url.Abstract: Translating Self Service Templates Self Service templates are available for Self Service users to use from the Self Service module. You can edit any of the English field values and provide corresponding values in the supported languages.

Url.Title: Translating Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Translating Quick Actions Another way to translate quick actions is through the Quick Actions Manager page.

Url.Title: Setting Up User Login
Url.Abstract: Setting Up User Login This section contains information about various login configurations. Topics In This Section

Url.Title: Login Priority
Url.Abstract: Login Priority The Login Priority page is where you define which login credentials should be used first when logging in.

Url.Title: Password Policy
Url.Abstract: Password Policy

Url.Title: Anonymous Login
Url.Abstract: Anonymous Login You can allow any user to access specific records and information without requiring a login ID and password. Such users are called anonymous. For example, you can allow anonymous users to create specific Request Offerings or access certain Knowledge articles when they click a link from an email or web page.

Url.Title: External Login
Url.Abstract: External Login This page lists users that have logged into the system externally.

Url.Title: Log in or Access Records Using URLs
Url.Abstract: Log in or Access Records Using URLs You can log into HEAT by clicking a URL that has been sent to you via email or by pasting the link in the address field of a browser, or by clicking a link that has been embedded in your company web page. You can also log in the same way, by clicking URLs that will take you to your authentication or identity provider page, and then log into HEAT from there.

Url.Title: Using the Identity Store
Url.Abstract: Using the Identity Store The Identity Store Workspace The Identity Store workspace lists all users who have login access to HEAT . These users have login IDs and passwords.

Url.Title: Session Inactivity Timeout
Url.Abstract: Session Timeout You can define the time (in minutes) that the current login session can remain inactive before the system automatically times out. The specified timeout is effective the moment a user logs in.

Url.Title: Logon History
Url.Abstract: Logon History You can get a list of when users log in from the Logon History page. While logged in as administrator, do one of the following:

Url.Title: Audit History
Url.Abstract: Audit History As an administrative tool, the audit history shows metadata changes. It does not show actual record changes.

Url.Title: Performance
Url.Abstract: Performance If your database is running slow or the application data is not synchronizing correctly, you can perform some simple actions to clear things up.

Url.Title: Notifications
Url.Abstract: Notifications You can create notifications for maintenance or release issues. These notifications appear to users when they log in for the first time, but not after that.

Url.Title: HEAT Development Project/Package
Url.Abstract: HEAT Development Project/Package This option is for Premise users only. Please refer to the Operations Configuration Manual for information on this feature.

Url.Title: Expressions
Url.Abstract: Expressions Expressions are a combination of common mathematical values and HEAT proprietary functions that can be used within searches, quick actions, dashboards, workflows, and business rules. The power of expressions gives you more control over your results. You can enter literal string constants, functions, or expression delimiters.

Url.Title: Constructing Expressions
Url.Abstract: Constructing Expressions A function, field reference, or calculated expression must be enclosed in an expression bracket. This syntax is a dollar sign with parenthesis:

Url.Title: Type Conversions
Url.Abstract: Type Conversions In certain contexts, values from one data type can be converted to another data type, either implicitly or explicitly.

Url.Title: Operators
Url.Abstract: Operators The following categories of operators are supported: The operators supported in HEAT are: The following table illustrates the order of precedence of the operators, from highest to lowest precedence.

Url.Title: Null Values
Url.Abstract: Null Values Initial Value for Fields For all four of the major field types (logical fields, number fields, DateTime fields, and text fields), the initial value is null. It remains as a null value when you save the record unless you manually set the value or the value is set by an available rule (such as the initialization rule or saving rule.)

Url.Title: Expression Examples
Url.Abstract: Expression Examples This section describes various scenarios for using expressions.

Url.Title: Using Expressions in Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Using Expressions in Quick Actions Quick actions can employ full expression syntax, surrounded by $(). For example:

Url.Title: Using Expressions in Searches and Dashboards
Url.Abstract: Using Expressions in Searches and Dashboards Searches and dashboards can employ literal strings or expressions, such as:

Url.Title: Style Rule Expressions in the Form Editor
Url.Abstract: Style Rule Expressions in the Form Editor You can use expressions when defining style rules in the form editor. However, style rules only recognize specific words. The following table lists the recognized words:

Url.Title: Using Expressions in Business Rules
Url.Abstract: Using Expressions in Business Rules You can customize business rules by using expressions. Within the business rule in which you want to create an expression, click Edit . The Edit Business Rule window appears.

Url.Title: Built-in Functions
Url.Abstract: Built-in Functions Built-in functions can be used in various places: Each function description contains the following information:

Url.Title: Control Functions
Url.Abstract: Control Functions

Url.Title: ChildFold
Url.Abstract: ChildFold Iterates through the given child business objects, evaluating the given expression in the context of each of the child business objects. The results of the expression evaluations are aggregated using the aggregatorOperator parameter.

Url.Title: FindAncestor
Url.Abstract: FindAncestor Returns the nearest ancestor (upward in a hierarchy) object. Syntax FindAncestor(hierarchyBoRef, relatedBoRef, recId, searchPredicate)

Url.Title: ForEachChild
Url.Abstract: ForEachChild Iterates child object instances and computes a text value for each of them. These values are then optionally sorted, and then concatenated and separated by a specified delimiter.

Url.Title: GetBOValue
Url.Abstract: GetBOValue Returns the value of a field within an instance of a business object. Syntax GetBOValue(recId, boRecId, boRef, boField)

Url.Title: GetSRPValue
Url.Abstract: GetSRPValue Gets the service request parameter value. Syntax GetSRPValue(recId, parameterFieldName) Enabled for

Url.Title: IfAllSiblings
Url.Abstract: IfAllSiblings Conditionally executes a quick action based on the parent and siblings of the current object.

Url.Title: IsBOUnderChangeControl
Url.Abstract: IsBOUnderChangeControl Determines if a business object is under change control. See Working with CIs for information about the Is Under Change Control field.

Url.Title: IsTrueForAllChildren
Url.Abstract: IsTrueForAllChildren Checks to see if all child business objects of a specified parent business object meet a specified criteria.

Url.Title: SearchHierarchy
Url.Abstract: SearchHierarchy This function has been deprecated. Use FindAncestor instead.

Url.Title: SearchList
Url.Abstract: SearchList This function has been deprecated.

Url.Title: Current User Functions
Url.Abstract: Current User Functions

Url.Title: CurrentLoginID
Url.Abstract: CurrentLoginID Returns the login ID for the user associated with the current session. This is the LoginID field from the Details tab in the user profile.

Url.Title: CurrentSecurityGroup
Url.Abstract: CurrentSecurityGroup This function has been deprecated.

Url.Title: CurrentUserDisplayName
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserDisplayName Returns the display name (which is usually the first name and last name, but can be configured by the administrator) for the user associated with the current session.

Url.Title: CurrentUserEmail
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserEmail Returns the primary email address of the user associated with the current session. This is the Primary Email field from the Details tab in the user profile.

Url.Title: CurrentUserField
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserField Returns the value for the specified field for the current session. Syntax CurrentUserField(field)

Url.Title: CurrentUserIdentityType
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserIdentityType Returns the identity type (such as employee, vendor, and so on) of the user associated with the current session. Use this function if you have business rules that are associated with a certain identity type.

Url.Title: CurrentUserInfo1
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserInfo1 This function has been deprecated.

Url.Title: CurrentUserName
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserName This function has been deprecated. Use CurrentLoginID or CurrentUserDisplayName .

Url.Title: CurrentUserOrganizationalUnitName
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserOrganizationalUnitName Returns the name of the organizational unit for the user associated with the current session. This is the Organizational Unit field from Organization section of the Details tab in the user profile.

Url.Title: CurrentUserOrganizationalUnit
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserOrganizationalUnit Returns the RecID (unique record identifier) of the organizational unit of the user associated with the current session.

Url.Title: CurrentUserRecId
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserRecId Returns the recID (unique record identifier) for the user associated with the current session. Use this function to access other properties for a user if you already know the recID of the user.

Url.Title: CurrentUserRelatedObjectFieldValues
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserRelatedObjectFieldValues Returns information that is related to the user associated with the current session based on related fields.

Url.Title: CurrentUserRole
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserRole Returns the role associated with this session. For information about roles, see About Roles.

Url.Title: CurrentUserTeam
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserTeam Returns the primary team, as defined in the employee details form, for the user associated with the current session.

Url.Title: CurrentUserTeamIds
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserTeamIds Returns the full set of team IDs for the user associated with the current session, as reflected in the Teams tab for the user.

Url.Title: CurrentUserTeamNames
Url.Abstract: CurrentUserTeamNames Returns the full set of teams for the user associated with the current session, as reflected in the Teams tab for the user.

Url.Title: UserPresence
Url.Abstract: UserPresence This function has been deprecated.

Url.Title: Date Functions
Url.Abstract: Date Functions

Url.Title: CurrentDate
Url.Abstract: CurrentDate Returns the local date of today as of midnight this morning, as a DateTime value, of the current session.

Url.Title: CurrentDateStr
Url.Abstract: CurrentDateStr Returns the local date for today (but not the time) of the current session as a text value.

Url.Title: CurrentDateTime
Url.Abstract: CurrentDateTime Returns the local date and time of today, as a DateTime value, of the current session.Use this function to populate a field with today's date and time.

Url.Title: DateAdd
Url.Abstract: DateAdd Returns a local date and/or time obtained by adding the value of the interval parameter to the starting date and/or time. This function takes into account the units (defined by the datePart parameter) for the interval.

Url.Title: DateDiff
Url.Abstract: DateDiff Returns an integer value in the same units as the datePart parameter. The return value is the result of subtracting the first date and time from the second date and time.

Url.Title: DatePart
Url.Abstract: DatePart Returns the requested part (such as day, second, or quarter) of the local date. Syntax DatePart(part,date)

Url.Title: EndOfNextYear
Url.Abstract: EndOfNextYear Returns the local date of the last day of the following year, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: EndOfPreviousMonth
Url.Abstract: EndOfPreviousMonth Returns the local date of the last day of the previous month, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: EndOfThisMonth
Url.Abstract: EndOfThisMonth Returns the local date and time of the last day of the current month, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: EndOfThisYear
Url.Abstract: EndOfThisYear Returns the local date of the last day of this year, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: FormatDate
Url.Abstract: FormatDate Returns the local date and/or time formatted as specified. Syntax FormatDate(date, format) Enabled for

Url.Title: Last3Months
Url.Abstract: Last3Months Returns the date and time for the date that was three months ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: Last90Days
Url.Abstract: Last90Days Returns the local date and time for the date that was 90 days ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: Last365Days
Url.Abstract: Last365Days Returns the local date and time for the date that was 365 days ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: LastDays
Url.Abstract: LastDays Returns the local date and time for the day that is a certain amount of days ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: LastSevenDays
Url.Abstract: LastSevenDays Returns the local date and time for the date that was seven days ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: LastThirtyDays
Url.Abstract: LastThirtyDays Returns the local date and time for the date that was 30 days ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: LastWeeks
Url.Abstract: LastWeeks Returns the local date and time for a day that was a certain amount of weeks ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: LastYears
Url.Abstract: LastYears Returns the local date and time for a date that was a certain number of years ago, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: NextDays
Url.Abstract: NextDays Returns the local date and time for a date that is a certain number of days in the future, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: NextSevenDays
Url.Abstract: NextSevenDays This function has been deprecated.

Url.Title: SecondsToTime
Url.Abstract: SecondsToTime Converts a number of seconds to the equivalent duration in the form dd:hh:mm:ss. Syntax SecondsToTime(value)

Url.Title: StartOfNextYear
Url.Abstract: StartOfNextYear Returns the local date for the first day of next year, as of midnight on that day, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: StartOfPreviousMonth
Url.Abstract: StartOfPreviousMonth Returns the local date for the first day of the previous month, as of midnight on that day, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: StartOfThisMonth
Url.Abstract: StartOfThisMonth Returns the local date for the first day of this month, as of midnight on that day, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: StartOfThisYear
Url.Abstract: StartOfThisYear Returns the local date for the first day of this year, as of midnight on that day, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: ToClientTime
Url.Abstract: ToClientTime Converts a DateTime value from UTC time to the local time of the logged-in user. If you execute this function without the optional time parameter, returns the current local time associated with the current session.

Url.Title: Today
Url.Abstract: Today Returns the local date for today as of midnight this morning, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: Tomorrow
Url.Abstract: Tomorrow Returns the local date for tomorrow as of midnight tomorrow morning, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: Yesterday
Url.Abstract: Yesterday Returns the local date for yesterday, as of midnight yesterday morning, based on the local time of the current session.

Url.Title: Default User Functions
Url.Abstract: Default User Functions

Url.Title: DefaultUserName
Url.Abstract: DefaultUserName Returns the default user name for the user associated with the current session. Syntax

Url.Title: DefaultUserTeam
Url.Abstract: DefaultUserTeam Returns the default team associated with the current session. Syntax DefaultUserTeam() Enabled for

Url.Title: DefaultUserType
Url.Abstract: DefaultUserType Returns the default user type associated with the current session. Syntax DefaultUserType()

Url.Title: LDAP Functions
Url.Abstract: LDAP Functions

Url.Title: DN
Url.Abstract: DN Returns the entire distinguished name of the current instance. This expression is used when mapping fields for an LDAP connection. Only use this function in the LDAP expression field mappings.

Url.Title: ParseDn
Url.Abstract: ParseDn Parses a distinguished name. Only use this function in the LDAP expression field mappings. Syntax

Url.Title: Numeric and Currency Functions
Url.Abstract: Numeric and Currency Functions

Url.Title: Currency
Url.Abstract: Currency Converts the input parameter or parameters into a currency value. A currency value is a combination of the actual number value and the currency code, such as 3 USD.

Url.Title: CurrencyCode
Url.Abstract: CurrencyCode Returns the currency code of a currency value. A currency value is a combination of the currency amount and the currency code, such as 3 USD.

Url.Title: CurrencyValue
Url.Abstract: CurrencyValue Returns the currency amount of a currency value. A currency value is a combination of the currency amount and the currency code, such as 3 USD.

Url.Title: DefaultCurrencyCode
Url.Abstract: DefaultCurrencyCode Returns the default currency code of the current session. Syntax DefaultCurrencyCode()

Url.Title: DefaultCurrencySymbol
Url.Abstract: DefaultCurrencySymbol Returns the default currency symbol, for example $ or ¥, for the user associated with the current session. This is the value in the Currency field on the Currency page for the organizational profile.

Url.Title: Round
Url.Abstract: Round Rounds a value to the number of decimal places specified. Returns the integer nearest the value parameter. If the fractional component of the value parameter is halfway between two integers, one of which is even and the other odd, then this function returns the even number. This is called banker's rounding and it minimizes rounding errors that result from consistently rounding a midpoint value in a single direction.

Url.Title: RoundDown
Url.Abstract: RoundDown Rounds a value down to the previous whole number. Syntax RoundDown(value) Enabled for Parameter

Url.Title: RoundUp
Url.Abstract: RoundUp Rounds a value up to the next whole number. Syntax RoundUp(value) Enabled for Parameter Return Value

Url.Title: Numeric Functions
Url.Abstract: Numeric Functions

Url.Title: NumericEmpty
Url.Abstract: NumericEmpty Returns null. Use this function to clear contents of a number field. Syntax NumericEmpty()

Url.Title: String Functions
Url.Abstract: String Functions

Url.Title: Decode
Url.Abstract: Decode Compares one expression to one or more other expressions. When the base expression matches a search expression, returns the corresponding result expression. When no match is found, returns the default expression when specified, or null when it is not. This function is similar to an if-then function.

Url.Title: EmptyString
Url.Abstract: EmptyString Returns an empty text value. Use this function to clear the contents of a field. Syntax EmptyString()

Url.Title: Find
Url.Abstract: Find Returns the starting position of the first instance of a specific text value within a field value.

Url.Title: FloatToStr2
Url.Abstract: FloatToStr2 Converts a number value to a text value with two decimal places. Syntax FloatToStr2(number)

Url.Title: Len
Url.Abstract: Len Returns an integer value that is the length of the text, including empty spaces. Syntax Len(text) Enabled for

Url.Title: Substring
Url.Abstract: Substring Returns a string containing a substring of consecutive characters from another string. Syntax

Url.Title: ToLowerCase
Url.Abstract: ToLowerCase Converts a text value to all lower case characters and returns the result. It does not change any characters that are not upper case.

Url.Title: ToString
Url.Abstract: ToString Converts the input value to text form. Syntax ToString(value,precision) Enabled for Parameters Return Value

Url.Title: ToUpperCase
Url.Abstract: ToUpperCase Converts a text value to all upper case characters and returns the result. It does not change any characters that are not lower case.

Url.Title: Trim
Url.Abstract: Trim Returns the input after trimming off all leading and trailing white space characters. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.char.iswhitespace%28v=vs.110%29.aspx for a definition of white space characters.

Url.Title: System Functions
Url.Abstract: System Functions

Url.Title: CurrentBrowserCulture
Url.Abstract: CurrentBrowserCulture Returns the culture code associated with the current session. Syntax CurrentBrowserCulture()

Url.Title: CurrentBrowserTimezoneOffset
Url.Abstract: CurrentBrowserTimezoneOffset Returns the difference in minutes between the local timezone of the current session and UTC.

Url.Title: CurrentGlobalCurrency
Url.Abstract: CurrentGlobalCurrency This function has been deprecated. Use DefaultCurrencySymbol instead.

Url.Title: EncodeLink
Url.Abstract: EncodeLink Encodes a text value to be used in a query part of a URL. Some ASCII characters, such as commas and brackets, are considered to be unsafe inside an argument, so they need to be encoded. Non-ASCII characters must also be encoded. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_string for information about URL encoding. See URL Encoding Reference for a list of URL codes.

Url.Title: EvalField
Url.Abstract: EvalField Evaluates an expression stored in a given field. This function is useful for getting the value from other business objects as long as you have the RecID (unique record identifier).

Url.Title: GetActionVariable
Url.Abstract: GetActionVariable Returns the action variable. Syntax GetActionVariable(arg1) Enabled for Parameters Return Value

Url.Title: GetApplicationId
Url.Abstract: GetApplicationId Returns the application ID associated with the current session. This is the fully qualified domain name of the application (tenant).

Url.Title: GetCounterValue
Url.Abstract: GetCounterValue Returns the current value of the specified counter. For information on counters, see Using Counters.

Url.Title: GetGlobal
Url.Abstract: GetGlobal Returns the value of the global constant specified. See Defining Global Constants and Default Global Constants.

Url.Title: GetNextCounter
Url.Abstract: GetNextCounter Instructs the system to increment the specified counter and then returns the incremented value of a counter.

Url.Title: GetSurveyName
Url.Abstract: GetSurveyName Returns the ID of a survey and URL encodes it. Syntax GetSurveyName(surveyName) Enabled for

Url.Title: GetSurveyURL
Url.Abstract: GetSurveyURL Returns the URL of the survey application. Syntax GetSurveyURL() Enabled for Parameters Return Value

Url.Title: HOPCalcDuration
Url.Abstract: HOPCalcDuration Calculates the duration, in seconds, between two dates and times based on an hours of operation (HOP) schedule. The HOP calculation is based on the HOP schedule, which is set in the application configuration.

Url.Title: HOPCalcTargetDate
Url.Abstract: HOPCalcTargetDate Calculates the end date and time based on a start date, hours of operation (HOP) schedule, and an interval.

Url.Title: HtmlEncode
Url.Abstract: HtmlEncode Returns the HTML encoded form of the text that was passed in. Some characters in HTML have special meaning and the browser does not render them literally. For example, the browser interprets any text enclosed by angle brackets (< and >) as an HTML tag that describes the formatting of the text. To display HTML code literally, including all of the syntax, it must be HTML encoded when sent to the browser. The system replaces certain characters that have special meaning in HTML with other characters. For example, the system replaces a greater than sign (>) with >, replaces the less than sign (<) with <, and replaces the ampersand sign (&) with &.

Url.Title: IsNull
Url.Abstract: IsNull Checks to see if a value is null. Syntax IsNull(value) Enabled for Parameter Return Value Boolean value. Returns true if the value parameter is null; otherwise, returns false.

Url.Title: Local
Url.Abstract: Local Returns the localized value of the neutral equivalent. Syntax Local(fieldName) Enabled for Parameters

Url.Title: NewGuid
Url.Abstract: NewGuid Generates and returns a new globally unique identifier (GUID) that can be used to uniquely identify something, usually a business object instance.

Url.Title: nvl
Url.Abstract: nvl First determines if the value of the first parameter is null. If it is, it returns the value of the second parameter.

Url.Title: Prompt
Url.Abstract: Prompt Displays a text box for the user to enter text and returns the text that the user entered. Syntax

Url.Title: PromptAndExecuteAction
Url.Abstract: PromptAndExecuteAction Asks a yes/no question and executes a quick action depending on the answer. Syntax

Url.Title: SecureServerURL
Url.Abstract: SecureServerURL Returns the secure (HTTPS) base URL of the HEAT Application Server. For HEAT Cloud customers, an example is https://<company_name>.saasit.com. (For Premise customers, your system administrator determines your HEAT Application Server URL.)

Url.Title: ServerURL
Url.Abstract: ServerURL Returns the base URL of the HEAT Application Server. For HEAT Cloud customers, an example is http://<company_name>.saasit.com. (For Premise customers, your system administrator determines your HEAT Application Server URL.)

Url.Title: Type Conversion Functions
Url.Abstract: Type Conversion Functions

Url.Title: Boolean
Url.Abstract: Boolean Converts the input into a Boolean value. Syntax Boolean(input) Enabled for Parameter Return Value Boolean value. See Boolean Literals. See also Conversion to Boolean Values.

Url.Title: DateTime
Url.Abstract: DateTime Converts the input parameter into a local DateTime value. Syntax DateTime(value) Enabled for Parameter

Url.Title: Number
Url.Abstract: Number Converts the input parameter into a number value. Syntax Number(value) Enabled for Parameter Return Value

Url.Title: Workflow Object Blocks
Url.Abstract: Workflow Object Blocks HEAT includes the following workflow object blocks:

Url.Title: CMDB Import
Url.Abstract: CMDB Import Workflow Block The CMDB Import Block performs the SCCM integration. It has a parameter that starts the import from SCCM to the HEAT configuration management database (CMDB).

Url.Title: Create Object
Url.Abstract: Create Object Workflow Block Creates an object in the workflow. With the Create Object block, you can create a business object that is unrelated to the object in context.

Url.Title: DSM Integration
Url.Abstract: DSM Integration Workflow Block DSM Integration Workflow Block Exit Ports Properties Actions

Url.Title: DSM Sync
Url.Abstract: DSM Sync Workflow Block DSM Sync Workflow Block Exit Ports Properties Actions

Url.Title: Extended Task
Url.Abstract: Extended Task Workflow Block Extend Task Workflow Block Exit Ports Properties Actions

Url.Title: Get Approval
Url.Abstract: Get Approval Workflow Block Add approval stages to the workflow process. You can specify approvers, approval criteria, and timelines for approvals.

Url.Title: If
Url.Abstract: If Workflow Block Allows a Boolean decision to be made between fields, literal, system function, and global values. Depending on the outcome, the exit port can connect to a different block, creating a different path within the workflow. The exit ports in this block allow for paths based on true and false returns.

Url.Title: Insert Child Object
Url.Abstract: Insert Child Object Workflow Block Inserts a Child Object block into the workflow and defines the child object.

Url.Title: Insert Multi Child
Url.Abstract: Insert Multi Child Workflow Block Define a multiple-item request with the Insert Multi Child object. Insert Multi-Child Workflow Block

Url.Title: Invoke for Child
Url.Abstract: Invoke for Child Workflow Block This block invokes a workflow created for a child object. The exit ports allow for paths contingent upon the workflow being started, completed, and failing.

Url.Title: Invoke Workflow
Url.Abstract: Invoke Workflow Block This block invokes another workflow created within this business object. The exit ports allow for paths contingent upon the workflow being started, completed, and failing.

Url.Title: IPCM Voice Activity
Url.Abstract: IPCM Voice Activity Workflow Block IPCM Voice Activity Workflow Block Exit Ports Properties Actions

Url.Title: Join
Url.Abstract: Join Workflow Block This workflow block combines two or more workflow paths. For example, you can specify the required actions (paths) that must reach this Join block before the workflow can continue.

Url.Title: LDAP Sync
Url.Abstract: LDAP Sync Workflow Block This block performs a synchronization of an existing LDAP configuration. LDAP Sync Workflow Block

Url.Title: Notification
Url.Abstract: Notification Workflow Block Use the Notification block to define settings for email notifications. You can create automated messaging within the body of the email message as well as designate the recipient individuals and teams.

Url.Title: Quick Action
Url.Abstract: Quick Action Workflow Block Use the Quick Action workflow block to define a quick action to execute when a business process has completed. You can select an action associated with this business object.

Url.Title: Run for Child
Url.Abstract: Run for Child Workflow Block Specify a secondary workflow to run against each instance of a specified child record related to the current business object. Specify the relationship, Boolean operators and expressions.

Url.Title: Run for Search
Url.Abstract: Run for Search Workflow Block Specify a search that can trigger a quick action or invoke a supplemental workflow. For example, you can run a search for all active incidents, then generate a reminder or escalation notification.

Url.Title: Run Program
Url.Abstract: Run Program Workflow Block The Run Program block runs a connection to a remote host to import data. Run Program Workflow Block

Url.Title: Run Web Service
Url.Abstract: Run Web Service Workflow Block This block creates a quick action that runs a web service. Use the Run Web Service block to assemble the details needed to call an external web service such as cost service, data access, or notification. This involves defining the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) document, service and method to use, and then specifying the parameters.

Url.Title: SR DSM Integration
Url.Abstract: SR DSM Integration Workflow Block SR DSM Integration Workflow Block Exit Ports Properties

Url.Title: Start
Url.Abstract: Start Workflow Block Starts the workflow when the trigger fires. The trigger event can be a condition, a scheduled action, or a call from another workflow process. The Start block is required. The first action in the workflow is to create a record within the business object.

Url.Title: Stop
Url.Abstract: Stop Workflow Block Ends the workflow. The Stop block is required. Stop Workflow Block Exit Ports None. Properties

Url.Title: Switch
Url.Abstract: Switch Workflow Block Allows a Boolean decision to be made between fields, literal, system function, and global values. You can define multiple exit ports depending on the decision, routing the workflow to different blocks.

Url.Title: Task
Url.Abstract: Task Workflow Block Assigns a task to an employee or team, including task priority and timelines. Task Workflow Block

Url.Title: Task/Template Instantiation
Url.Abstract: Task/Template Instantiation Workflow Block Creates a task or template instance. Task/Template Instantiation Workflow Block

Url.Title: Update
Url.Abstract: Update Workflow Block Updates data within the context of the business object where an action is running. If executed at the beginning of the workflow, the action updates the record causing the instance or the workflow to run.

Url.Title: Wait
Url.Abstract: Wait Workflow Block Waits for a condition specified in the block to become true, or for a timer to expire. By default, exit ports for this block allow for separate workflow paths for these events.

Url.Title: Wait for Child
Url.Abstract: Wait for Child Workflow Block Waits for a condition specified in the block to become true for a child object, or for a timer to expire. By default, exit ports for this block allow for separate workflow paths based on these events.

Url.Title: Default Business Objects
Url.Abstract: Default Business Objects Listed are the default business objects provided with the current release. System objects (ie. logonhistory) do not support business rules and cannot be used to trigger a workflow event. Also, any business object system fields (ie. LastModDateTime) do not trigger a workflow.

Url.Title: Default Quick Actions
Url.Abstract: Default Quick Actions The list of quick actions available from the Action Menu depends on your context. Some quick actions are available only from the search results table or grid of the Incident workspace, while others are specific to the incident record or tab on the record.

Url.Title: Quick Action Templates
Url.Abstract: Quick Action Templates This section describes the parameters used when creating, duplicating, or editing a quick action.

Url.Title: Baseline
Url.Abstract: Baseline Quick Action Sets a standard parameter value for configuration items. For example, you can set the RAM for the production server to 4 GB.

Url.Title: Clone Object
Url.Abstract: Clone Object Quick Action Creates a copy of the selected record and overwrites the specified fields, including copying from One-to-One relationships.

Url.Title: Composite Action
Url.Abstract: Composite Action Quick Action Assembles complex quick actions based on other quick actions.

Url.Title: Create RFC for Variance
Url.Abstract: Create RFC for Variance Quick Action Creates a change object (request for change) for variance. When the RAM size is changed from the baseline to some other value, it varies from the baseline.

Url.Title: Create Variance Report
Url.Abstract: Create Variance Report Quick Action Creates a variance report for the configuration or Inventory Manager showing the changes that have been made since the last recorded baseline.

Url.Title: Export Data
Url.Abstract: Export Data Quick Action Use this quick action with the data export integration connection. See Data Export.

Url.Title: Export to Excel
Url.Abstract: Export to Excel Quick Action Creates a new MS Excel spreadsheet (.xlsx) containing the rows from a query created within its quick action wizard. The list of columns exported to MS Excel is the same as shown in the list view by default, but can be overridden or expanded here. Creates only one worksheet.

Url.Title: Insert Child Object
Url.Abstract: Insert Child Object Quick Action Inserts a child object into a form or grid, such as a new incident, field value, or a note.

Url.Title: Inventory Manager
Url.Abstract: Inventory Manager Quick Action

Url.Title: License Manager
Url.Abstract: License Manager Quick Action

Url.Title: Run Program
Url.Abstract: Run Program Quick Action Enables users to run a scheduled or unscheduled script to a remote data source.

Url.Title: Run Report
Url.Abstract: Run Report Quick Action Runs a specified report that has been created to support quick actions.

Url.Title: Run Web Service
Url.Abstract: Run Web Service Quick Action This is a quick action used to obtain information from a web service and is often used in conjunction with an update record quick action. You also can use it in conjunction with a business rule to calculate a parameter and then use it in a process.

Url.Title: Run for Child
Url.Abstract: Run for Child Quick Action Applies the quick action to a child object of the current business object. For example, you can run an update action and then export data to MS Excel. See Using the Run for Child Quick Action.

Url.Title: Search and Link
Url.Abstract: Search and Link Quick Action Searches for and links a business object record to another record. For example, you can link an employee record to an incident record. You can only link records in a relationship with your associated business object.

Url.Title: Send Email
Url.Abstract: Send Email Quick Action Use this quick action to compose an email to send to a designated person or group. For example, you can send a confirmation email when a change has been approved. The email can be populated with data, such as field values, functions, counters, or global values.

Url.Title: Send Mobile Notification
Url.Abstract: Send Mobile Notification Quick Action Compose a message to be sent to mobile devices for a designated person or group. For example, you can send a confirmation text when a change has been approved. The text can be populated with data, such as field values, functions, counters, or global values.

Url.Title: Start IPCM Voice Activity
Url.Abstract: Start IPCM Voice Activity Quick Action Configures and calls a web service for the FrontRange Voice (IPCM) application. Before configuring this quick action, you must set up the voice integration to HEAT. See Configuring Voice Integration.

Url.Title: UI Action
Url.Abstract: UI Action Quick Action Executes a quick action within the form or grid. You can switch to a designated child tab and open a blank form for a user to fill out. There is no way to pass parameters with this quick action. (Instead, use the Insert Child Record quick action.)

Url.Title: Update Object
Url.Abstract: Update Object Quick Action Updates an existing business object. Use the wizard to optionally add levels of granularity, constructing additional expressions restricting the viewing and usage of the quick action to certain field states.

Url.Title: Workflow Script
Url.Abstract: Workflow Script Quick Action This feature is currently not supported.

Url.Title: Template
Url.Abstract: Template Quick Action Displays a template where you can create a business object with pre-populated field values and child objects.

Url.Title: GSC Search and Link
Url.Abstract: GSC Search and Link Quick Action Searches the Global Software Catalog (GSC) and links a business object record to another record.

Url.Abstract: Quick Action Settings The following table contains the Action Settings for quick actions under Create New Action.

Url.Title: Object Templates
Url.Abstract: Object Templates The Object Templates Manager is a convenient way to view the new record templates for your business objects. When a user creates a new record, they have the option of choosing one of the defined quick action templates for that object, automatically entering data into certain fields.

Url.Abstract: Default Priority Values You can prioritize incidents, changes, and problems. Three criteria determine when objects are processed. By default, the object form utilizes the following fields for processing:

Url.Title: New Features
Url.Abstract: New Features The following new features and updates are included in this release. Not all features are available to customers using older versions.

Url.Title: Authors
Url.Abstract: Authors This online help was developed and written by the fabulous Kate Montressor and the lovely Julie McMullen.

Url.Title: Task Costs
Url.Abstract: Task Costs When a task is added to an Incident or Service Request record, and the task status is set to Complete, the actual cost is automatically added to the Cost Item tab and to the ITFM Cost Item workspace. See Cost Items.
